content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												While perhaps not worth the hype the series has generated over the years, this game is still very good. I really enjoyed the story, and the way it progressed really impressed me. The supporting cast aren't that great (something they improved in Mass Effect 2, sadly with the loss of the great story) but the fact that Shepard develops how you want him to while still remaining an interesting character is no mean feat.It is quite annoying that some conversations that give you options just ignore your choices and just go straight into what the game wants, and I guess it would be tough to make a game which allowed all that but then making games is tough. So I would've liked more freedom to do what I wanted rather than just what the game dictated. Nobody likes a game pretending you have a choice and then just ignoring it. That's just not cool.The combat is perfectly acceptable. I heartily recommend going with the combat-biotic fusion character as then you get the most fun out of your character while still remaining a heavy hitter with weapons. The squad-part of combat is really not at all important, as your squad is not all that effective and they can just about handle themselves. I'm quite glad that they did that though, as I prefer having a squad that does their own thing. They could have made them slightly more clever however. Overall, a very good game with a few drawbacks. Not a brilliant game, but a very good game nonetheless.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												And it begins! This game is incredible. I played this game close to 7 years after its release and it's still amazing. This game is perfect. The story is absolutely engrossing and something you can submerge yourself into, it's like a modern day Star Wars. The characters in this game are so well developed, the grow on you to the point you'll always consider them life long friends. This is an action RPG and the game lives up to that classification. The action is just as riveting as the decisions you'll need to make over the course of the game. Never before has a game put me on the edge of my seat, regarding the consequences of choices I've made. I love the freedom this game offers. The tension builds and builds as you reach the climax. The game play is intuitive and an enjoyable experience. As you build your characters skillsets, you experience such a natural incline of abilites and you can lots of options to build a character with combat skills suited to your preferences. This is game you'll remember. Interested in Mass Effect 2 or 3? Not sure if you'll enjoy Mass Effect because it's almost a decade old? Buy this game, you will not be dissapointed. Not only will it enrich your experience for Mass Effect 2 and 3, it's just downright a great game. You'll soon realize the more Mass Effect in your life, the better. Hell, I even suffered through playing Mass Effect 3 on origin....that's how great this game is!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I Should Go......Are the words that I occasionally see on the faces of people whom I introduce Mass Effect to. Naturally, it's a given response, since this game is a far cry from what many are used to on both the RPG and Shooting front. I remember almost throwing this game into the recycling bin while I had the PS3 version, since I couldn't figure out how to zoom out on the galaxy map (my fault entirely for forgetting that the circle button exists).Sure, the game does present a few faults here and there, such as the awkward shooting/cover mechanics, absurdly long cooldown times for powers, optional yet completely barren side missions, limited auto-save points, [some] overpowered enemy biotics as well as a few other caveats that I won't go into detail here, which can completely cripple someone's interest in Mass Effect. A sad thing, since the feeling of carrying over your complete save to Mass Effect 2 is unparalleled on so many levels. Bioware has always been a dominant forefront for the story driven rpg market, and Mass Effect is no exception. Thus, enjoyment as a whole can be severely limited if the player refrains from making a personal investment in the overall lore, story and characters. And yes, Mass Effect goes above and beyond in providing all three, while also establishing an atmosphere of its own, which makes it stand out heavily among all the other space games on the market. Top-tier Canadian science fiction everybody!Many of the choices you make in this game will impact you later, especially when carrying over your saves to the next two games. Who you save, what you say, when you choose to do missions, which path you follow, undoubtedly adds a lot of "Mass" to the "Effect" of your decisions, and definitely adds weight to what happens later in the first game alone. Plus, the PC port is outstanding, enabling you to use most, if not all of your powers during combat in real time, rather than always opening the power wheel on the console versions. Equipment management and gun modding is also much more direct/less in your face due to the redesigned menu system. The new hacking minigames are also a nice touch as well. It's almost as if PC was Bioware's most prioritized platform from the get-go. Definitely better than the delayed PS3 version, which encountered many lip-sync errors, missing textures and frame rate issues. Also didn't help that it always took 12 seconds to save, where the PC port only requires half a second, with the addition of a very handy quick save button.You'll need to install a few mods and edit the .ini files though if you wish to remove some small hitches, but that can be accomplished easily through the many worthwhile guides for this game (I'd recommend uncapping the game's framerate and installing MEUITM, which allows you to run the game higher than 720p and upscales a lot of old textures). It's not necessary, but the experience is undoubtedly more rewarding with those fixes.I won't go into detail on any of the main story points and characters, since I wish for anyone reading this review who doesn't own the game yet to find out for themselves. Sure, Mass Effect isn't for everybody, and it might seem underwhelming at first for many Star Wars/Doctor Who enthusiasts out there, but the series as a whole quickly makes a name for itself if you give it time, especially if you make it to the third game, and the eventual fourth if you love the series that much : )

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Not quite the full kilo MASS EFFECT is a mixed bag of a game: everything about it is good in some ways but not in others. The most notable achievement perhaps is the rich storyline and detailed universe created by the developers (there is plenty to read here -- I started by reading every word but confess to scanning some texts as the game progressed). The graphics are good in parts but not in others (I know this game came out in 2007 but then so did Crysis). The voice acting is overall pretty good and there are plenty of branches to the dialogue trees. And this is where MASS EFFECT’s strengths lie: in the role playing aspects of the game. You’re given the opportunity to be the good guy or the not so good guy, depending on how you wish to play. Less successful is the combat, which, for the most part, failed to engage. Also the side missions are very repetitive and dull. The vehicle you get to drive on numerous occasions bounces around like a drunken bouncy thing, and there are endless elevators that take too long to ascend or descend. Oh, and the UI for selecting skills, weapons etc. is needlessly complex. Overall MASS EFFECT is worth playing but the whole experience is oddly detached and vaguely unsatisfying. I have MASS EFFECT 2 also. I understand it’s much improved on the first.3/5

Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is great fun. I couldn't recommended it more. The graphics are good, the gameplay is engaging and the voice acting is good. Jenifer Hale does a great job voicing fem shep, (don't play the male shep line because it is that good). The great thing about the choices you make in this game is that they carry over into the next two games. There is strong support for this game from the community which is super useful if your suck.Some things (which aren't necessarily bad just noteable):somepeople may find it unusual playing this game without the jump feature (particularly if you havent played a game without it)the game is getting on now and you may need to put it into compatiability mode or give admin rights, and some people may want to tweak a few settings (there are heaps of tweak guides out there)you want to save, lots. even just to save yourself if a very rare glitch happens but its very easy to get sucked into this game and forget to save, and then to lose all your progress. But there are relatively frequent autosaves. It has serious replayabilty too, which is an added bonus. Also, there are dlc for this game one free and one you can pay for both adds to the game but not necessary there is loads of content. i hope you have as much fun playing this game as i have.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Mass Effect is quite simply my favourite game series. It all started with this first installment which introduces us to an immersive open galaxy where the decisions we make through gameplay and dialogue options shape our journey along throughout our time in the game. You play as a Commander of your own ship and are tasked with bringing a rogue Spectre to justice. Along the way you visit numerous planets and environments with a squad of team mates you recruit along the way. The character interactions between you and your squad truly shape your experience playing the game as you begin to learn about their backgrounds and understand their motivations for fighting alongside you.The plot is straightforward with an engaging villain (the rogue Spectre Saren) and develpos at a steady pace with many more options for side quests that help build and shape the world building, or galaxy building I should say.  Playing as Commander Shepard you have the option to play nicely (paragon) or rather roughly (renegade) while dealing with your dialogue wheel options, allowing to to shape your character's personality. I personally prefer the paragon route.Any downsides I would mention are the somewhat clunky mechanics during fire fights and the difficulty there can sometimes be when you try and fail to take cover. The graphics have aged compared to the more recent installments but  can still be considered decent. I highly reccommend giving the Mass Effect game series a go. It will change your perception of sci-fi RPGs for the better, and not to mention there are two jaw-dropping sequels to sink your teeth into after this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
 There isn't enough positive words to describe my love for the game and it's counter-parts. TL;DR - Brilliant storyline, immersive galaxy and worlds to visit. The characters and chemistry between you and character you meet are one of the things that makes Mass Effect so great. A truly brilliant RPG for those who love Science Fiction and action games.As you can tell by the amount of time I've spent playing this game, I've done quite a few playthroughs (I've lost count of how many times I've played Mass Effect, but it's an abnormally large number). Bioware really has a knack of combining a great storyline and character development together with gameplay and customisation. Of course, this was before EA really got them by the balls and milked their franchise dry. First things first, here is what I LOVED about this game. - The story (as mentioned many times above) could not be any better;  immediately you're thrown into the story, as Commander Shepard, with the Alliance Navy, on your way to Eden Prime to check out some Prothean artifacts and screw up whatever plan the bad guys had going.  The different plot points blend together perfectly; the introduction of Saren Arterius, the Geth, the Citadel and your Spectre ranking, it all just comes and goes so well. The interaction with characters and potential romance options really puts the player in the game and the experiences really stick with you.- The lore/canon behind the different points of the game and the background to the game is brilliant; I've spent many hours external of the game reading up on the Mass Effect Wikia page about different planets, key events (like the discovery of the Mass Relay near Pluto) and the technology seen within the game. Players can learn everything and more about the Mass Effect universe without even leaving the game, the codex contains lots and lots of sub-sections pointing to various information about the universe, with the player being able to add more and more accessible canon stories to the codex by interacting with certain items or buildings in game.- Character customisation is really in-depth and customisable; right off the bat, you are given the choice to edit your character's name, appearance, classification and background story. The appearance customisation options are alright, it's pretty default across a lot of RPG games. The class system is great also, with different classes offering the player different weapon choices, in-game powers and abilities. By selecting a character's background story, it really allows you to set up your characters morals for whatever way you wish to play;  whether you want to be a badass Male/Female Shepard who doesn't ask questions and shoots first, or a negotiator, who can talk their way out of anything , you have those choices in Mass Effect.- In-game levelling up and point assignment to you and your squadmates works very well; you have lots of options to add points to specific abilites that will become more accurate, powerful or varied with you and your team in combat and in dialogue. You can also access all your squad's character profiles on the Normandy and customise each one individually, as well as assign different squadmates to you with different missions.- The variety of weapons and mods available is huge to say the least; you can modify any weapon to have different effects on enemies, have a fast fire rate or more accuracy to name a few, as well as purchase or loot newer, more powerful weapons and equip them to you and your squadmates. The same is said for armor and omni-tools, which too can be upgraded by newer items. Now, for the things I was not so much a fan of in Mass Effect. - Off the bat I'm going to appeal to any of you graphic predators; this game is not high-end, cutting edge in the graphics department, it's pretty meh for a game that came out in 2007, compare to the likes of Assassin's Creed or Crysis that came out the same year. But available mods can greatly improve in-game textures and such if it really bothers you.- In-game, the mechanics of combat and everything combat-related is not really that great; the whole cover system, FOV and freeze screen selection is alright, but the newer Mass Effect 2 and 3 definitely improve on this game's mechanics.- The exploration options in the game are pretty linear, but definitely better than Mass Effect 2 and 3. Every world just kind of looks the same but in different colours or with a few different bases re-arranged. The mako is also a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to command around when exploring, getting stuck on mountain sides or in ditches and causing a lot of awkward situations. To conclude my review of Mass Effect;  this game and it's counter-parts are my pride and joy of video games. The game overall is so well made and the elements of it just work together fantastically, and for   £7.99, I think it's worth every penny   (or wait until the Steam sales, where I've seen it sell for £1.99 many times).I highly recommend you invest in this game if you like RPGs, Science Fiction or want to play a game you'll get lost in over and over again, for hours on end.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Well the big♥♥♥♥♥Space Opera RPG is pretty decent. It has got downsides, like having unremarkable gameplay resemblance to past Bioware games (most notably KotOR 1+2), elevator sim mini-games, half of the weapon and armor upgrades being completely useless, level scaling (why.jpg), copy-paste dungeon layouts (dungeon meaning the exact same buildings on every side-quest planet), and character building + skill trees that are so easy and limiting that it makes character/party builds in Final Fantasy VII look complex (which is not so surprising seeing the dichotomy between the KotOR games and their earlier games, Baldur's Gate for example). Also semi spoiler warning, the background lore and characters are very reminiscent of KotOR games. It is not direct copypaste but it is noticeable, but the quests and characters have their own unique flavors to them.But what's great about it? The story, music, characters, and the element of choice in the game. I clocked 62 hours into the game because the characters in my party entertained me (mostly Wrex) and the feeling of traveling to distant galaxies to explore them (and there are MANY of them, you'll be playing for hours) as a captain of my own ship and alien crew was too much fun. I would recommend a playthrough.

												Well the big♥♥♥♥♥Space Opera RPG is pretty decent. It has got downsides, like having unremarkable gameplay resemblance to past Bioware games (most notably KotOR 1+2), elevator sim mini-games, half of the weapon and armor upgrades being completely useless, level scaling (why.jpg), copy-paste dungeon layouts (dungeon meaning the exact same buildings on every side-quest planet), and character building + skill trees that are so easy and limiting that it makes character/party builds in Final Fantasy VII look complex (which is not so surprising seeing the dichotomy between the KotOR games and their earlier games, Baldur's Gate for example). Also semi spoiler warning, the background lore and characters are very reminiscent of KotOR games. It is not direct copypaste but it is noticeable, but the quests and characters have their own unique flavors to them.But what's great about it? The story, music, characters, and the element of choice in the game. I clocked 62 hours into the game because the characters in my party entertained me (mostly Wrex) and the feeling of traveling to distant galaxies to explore them (and there are MANY of them, you'll be playing for hours) as a captain of my own ship and alien crew was too much fun. I would recommend a playthrough.

number of helpful: 36 of 69 people (52%) found this review helpful31 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Mass Effect is pretty cool, I guess.You play as Shepard, who can be either male or female, but I played him as a man, so I will be addressing him as a he.Sorry Anita. The game takes place in the future where I somehow haven't conquered the world. Humanity, in its efforts to into space, exluding Poland, find a ancient alien relic called the Mass Relay at the edge of the solar system. They activate it, which is apparently a big no-no, and starts a interstellar war with a alien race called the Turians, it's okay though because you can bang one later. All greviances lost. Depending on the backstory you picked for Shepard, there is a chance he can compete with Batman on the world's deadest parents competition. As part of the Earth military, Shepard is sent off to a planet called Eden Prime where he must find out what happened to the country bumpkins and their space farms. He finds corpses, oh no! After the death of a Spectre, this games version of the hall monitors, Shepard is brought to the forefront of the galactic community as the first human hall monitor. Gonna monitor those halls so good. Through his Star Wars journey, Shepard discovers new friends, bitter enemies, and discovers his infatuation for blue buttcheeks, you go Shepard, get that blue berry. The combat is a mix between RPG elements and cover based shooting. You hide behind chest-high walls while popping out occasionally to shoot some fool or hit them with your Jedi mind powers. Like all older Bioware games, Mass Effect likes to tell you what's going on. There is a codex that covers aliens, places, alien places, weapons, alien weapons, goblin darts, and historical events, and alien historical events... Did I mention the aliens? They're kind of important.  I appreciate the time they took into making the game feel like it has it's own world instead of just being a series of events. The story isn't the greatest thing ever, but it does enough to get you lost in it and forgetting that you live on a raft going down the Mississippi because you won one too many hobo fights without throwing the match. Let's see you catch me now, Booker. Should you play Mass Effect? The characters are fun to be around and the story and gameplay is engaging enough to keep you interested. Your journey for blue butt cheeks should last you a few hours and it will probably keep you interested enough to play the sequel. Not the second sequel though, don't do that to yourself, you're beautiful and don't deserve that. I give Mass Effect two butt cheeks out of ten.  President Kennedy was the fastest random speaker in the world with upwards of 350 words per minute. Also, I have a curator now, you should probably check that out if you like reading the stupid crap I type out on here. You can find it here.http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Fantastic. Absolutely incredible. A space-faring action RPG!I love the crap out of this game. The combat, the weapons, the skill tree, the story, everything. Fabulous. Well done, Bioware.The story is enthralling, and you really feel like you're fighting to save the galaxy. The twists and turns are delicious and surprising. The combat system is fantastic. Finally a run-and-gun style of game that doesn't require you to hunt around for tons of freaking ammo. Instead guns have limitless ammo, but you can't fire too much or they'll overheat and be useless for a short time. Really a great mechanic, I love it. Scrounging and searching for ammo while playing was always annoying and immersion breaking for me in other games. The skill tree is great, very in-depth. You have a lot of choices to make and can make a unique character. I could play this game twenty times twenty different ways and STILL have different paths to take and different characters to create. Well done.The voice acting is fantastic. Love it.Overall a wonderful game. 10/10

number of helpful: 17 of 32 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Even if I give the game a thumbs up, this one is not for me. There are a few things that really put me off from playing through this game. The combat system is horrible. Fallout 3 struggled to not become a FPS and somehow it worked for the most part, but in this game it just doesn't work either way. It's not a FPS and not an action RPG either. The loot system has been 'simplified' to a point where you keep getting the same items over and over again. You can modify weapons and ammo though.The story is okay, but it didn't really catch me. Maybe the quite obvious build up for the main character to become the saviour of the universe was a bit too much. The voice acting for the main character does its part by simply being not good.You can travel to other systems than the ones covered by the main story, but they are boring and at best filled with some generic structures without any deeper meaning. You explore those planets using a vehicle that has one of the worst controls and physics I've ever encountered in a computer game.The visuals are good for a game from 2008, but the music doesn't really work for the title. It's very bland electronic music that would rather fit in an elevator.I won't finish the game even if I invested over 16 hours into it so far as I don't see it becoming really interesting and the overall gameplay is just not satisfying. Why I still give it a thumbs up? I still think it's worth a try even if I personally don't like it.

Mass Effect 2 might have fixed these issues but at the cost of the more deeper RPG elements of this one.The sense of scale and all the little story elements that are hidden in Mass Effect make it a great game, well worth replaying even a few years after release, even knowing it all amounts to nothing (ME3)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												590 hours.  Thats 24 unblinking, unsleeping days with the crew of the Normandy.According to the combined statistics of Steam, and Origin. Over a hundred fourty hours went into the original Mass Effect (four playthroughs), 289 hours into Mass Effect 2 (six playthroughs), and 219 hours into Mass Effect 3 (two compleate playthroughs, many incompleate) and 8 hours into ME4 Andromeda.Commander Shepard and her crew(no one should play as male Shep imho), have done plenty of galaxy saving, and stirring up,  under my control. They fought, robots, clones, politicians, and reporters. They made love to aliens, hate to aliens, and even saved a race from going compleatly extinct!  We laughed, cried, got wasted, and most importantly fought beside one another through thick and thin.They're my friends.OK, they're not really my friends; claiming to be buddies with imaginary characters is a little too geeky even for me. The Mass Effect series is not without its flaws, and some are truly Reaper-sized. But it has gripped me like nothing else in the history of video games, and video games and I go back a pretty long way (but I'll never betoo old for video games)!The Mass Effect universe is that rare thing—a fully-realized science fiction game setting that stands up to the likes of Star Trek or Star Wars. The universe in which the games take place has a rich and complex backstory, and even better, it's not a rich and complex back story that the player has to have info-dumped into his head. This isn't The Old Republic, where you have to read thousands of awful Kevin J. Anderson "Extended Universe" novels and have a working knowledge of the seven prime forms of lightsaber combat to get the most out of the game.There's depth in the backstory, but it's not the kind of depth that ever compelled me to memorize the game's codex entries. (Do you really need to know that the "First Contact War" between humans and Turians started because humans activated a mass relay in violation of council law and that the war culminated in the siege of Shanxi? No. It's wonderful flavor, but it's not mandatory knowledge.) The world is alive and compellingly real just through dialogue and character actions, without needing endless narration. The first game's opening title crawl essentially says, "This is the future and aliens are real and you are a space soldier. Go." That's enough.Instead of a galactic civics lesson, Mass Effect focuses on a human, the forever-first-nameless Commander Shepard, and her fight against the ancient Reapers, an enemy that aims to rid the galaxy of advanced sentient life for a whole bunch of really complicated reasons. That fight is the central focus of all three games, though Shepard's path from soldier to savior twists and turns and doubles back on itself like a demented snake.

content:

												Great game. If you like RPGs, then you'll love this game. I only played ME3 before I played any other Mass Effect games, and this one has proved why its a must have in only 8 hours of play. Pros:-Runs well on my system (i5 3570k GTX 770) its a 6 year old game so I think I'd be right to assume that it should rune fine on most systems -has extensive dialogue options -Interesting plot-Good graphics for the time-Characters are interesting-The ambiance of locations really make the game feel alive! For example, the Citadel. -The gameplay is fun, and not very conky-I find that the cover system is a lot more advanced than the ones that are offered in other AAA games released today, its pretty adaptive. Cons: -The inventory system isn't all that great-Sometimes there's a bit of screen tearing -If you don't like RPGs and don't really care much about lore and are looking for an fps, then this game won't really stand out for you. Overall, its a great game, and it never hurts to pick it up on a sale and try it. You will most probably enjoy it! 9.5/10

												This game is one of the best games, that has ever been created. Drew Karpyshyn wrote a legendary story around the Mass Effect title. The music is amazing and intense, gets you every time. The planets are fascinating, the side missions are fun, and the story once again... I had to play this game twice. First time i didn't complete any side missions, because the story grabbed me, and didn't let go. I wanted to kill that turian so bad, and everytime i got close, something happened, or some major information turned up why the Protheans died. It took me about 11 hours for the first run, but i realised, that this game has so many planets, and many more assignments, and I started all over again. It took more than 20 hours to get to the end this time, but it was totally worth it. Every minute of this is game is a gem. Oh, and if you decide to play this game, then consider every decision you make. They may have severe outcome in ME2 and 3.If you liked this game, and it's story, you will probably like Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic as well, and if you like reading, I would suggest, that the Darth Bane trilogy is the one to read, from Drew Karpyshyn.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												This is the start of something special. Three games and 100 hours later I sat back and thought "wow - that was a hell of a ride". A superior game in terms of story telling and character development, combat is a second consideration in my opinion, far outpaced by getting to known the Mass Effect galaxy. If you want an RPG adventure that takes you to some amazing locations with a detailed and intriguing story full of consequences for your actions and a good dosage of humour and sorrow, start your journey here and I don't hink you'll regret it. Be warned that this is not a heavily action packed game - there are long periods of dialogue and some people won't want to be burdened with that. This game *might* not be for the action hungry.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												I played Mass Effect twice, once with a female engineer Shepard and once with a male vanguard Shepard. If you like the Dragon Age series and you don't mind a more shooter-like style of fighting, this is the game for you. But even if you're not familiar with it, this game is a lot of fun for everyone I would say.The character development and the decisions (good/evil) make things interesting and all the different companions really add to the storyline. The vehicle (Mako) is an absolute nightmare but you kinda get used to it and I even spoke of it fondly by the end of the game.The planets and views in this game are absolutely stunning, even if you don't have the best graphics (like me). I started Mass Effect 2 now because I loved this game so much.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												It did a great job of introducing me to a whole bunch of new philosophical questions at a very basic level when I was 15-16. A great alternative to pamphlets when you need to talk to your 15 year old kid about ending the life support of some crazy lady's husband.One of the available side-quests (colonist background) was one of my favorite moments in any game I've ever played, and was more touching to me than even something like Undertale was.This game played a small role in shaping the person I am, but it did so by presenting me with options and making me choose from them - not by forcing me to play the galaxy's hero or villain. Highly recommended, although parts of the game do show their age these days.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Wow. What a fantastic experience this game was.I've heard so much about this game before actually getting myself to finally play it. Mainly because I'm not a fan of SCI-FI or shooter. Well I wasn't, before I started Mass Effect. This game is incredible. It will drag you in with it's fantastic gameplay, brilliantly written story with massive lore, amazing character development, beautiful music, beautiful landscapes, unique atmosphere, masterfully done voice acting and some of what are probably one of the most memorable characters in the game history. This is one of the rare games I actually finished. I have the tendency to play too many things at once to focus on a single game alone. This game, however, was an exception and getting it was probably one of the best decisions I've made in my life. I got it on sales for an € or so, but it is not only worth it's original price, but double that. I recommend this game to everyone everywhere that cherishes brilliant dialogues, deep character development, huge lore behind the main story, for people that don't want to just walk straight forward and shoot stuff, but for people that enjoy exploring the world they are in, for people that enjoy making decisions and think logically. Truly a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Great futuristic RPG based on our universe in somewhat fantasy setting. You play as commander Shepard who is pretty much a one man, a one ship crew army. Wont spoil much, this game has great story, a lot of characters and character interaction via cut scene dialogues. Great galaxy to explore with a lot of planets to land on, stations to visit and side quests to do. Has a lot of choice and consequence so think carefully what you say, as the response will shape your character to be good or evil. Game has great visuals, voice acting and animations. Make sure you keep your saves if you plan on playing ME 2, ME 3, etc., as you can transfer them and keep your progress and story over to the next game. I enjoyed this a lot, one of the best if not the best sci-fi RPG of my time.

Posted: July 22, 2011
												This is one of those games that people seem to either love or just like.  I have never found anyone who hated it.  I am firmly in the "love" category.  One of those singleplayer experiences that you will remember forever.  Also, another one of the rare games that I find myself coming back to over and over again.  Like Deus Ex, it is basically a shooter with RPG elements (a TPS instead of an FPS).  Also like Deus Ex, you will find that there are often choices that you face in campaign that will change the gameplay and direction of the rest of the game.  Mass Effect has a perfect balance of choice, action, customizing, freedom, and intrigue to keep you coming back over and over again.

												Great game, love the comabt, story, and in-game exploration. Few issues with textures and going into cover during combat, but it is what it is.Huge negative for me is the poor save system. Really hate losing 10-15 minutes of progress just because the game doesn't save because I didn't reach a virtual checkpoint. I can manually save all I want, but I'll still be forced to revert back to the last checkpoint the game saved at. This is a huge issue especially during boss battles. Sure, I shouldn't be able to save during a fight or in the boss arena, but I should be able to save one room before the boss and not 50 rooms back.I'm playing on Normal and love the game, but I think I'll be forced to play on Easy just so I can get around this asinine save system.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Mass Effect is an amazing game.I first played it years ago when I was a young teenager,  when it was the only ME game out there and it shaped what I expected of gaming from then on. Everything from the atmosphere of the game (the music in particular is something to behold) to the narrative and how it plays out all feels well thought-out and engaging. Some of the plot and side-missions feel like they're plucked from generic sci-fi plotlines and remuddled a bit, but in ME's own way, it owns those factors and you no longer think "That whole alien queen speaking telepathically to someone has been done before" and rather think "Mass Effect did it and did it well." Your rampage across the galaxy to find this villain who's become a harbinger for the end of life as we know it is fun, and you care about it. Is it the same as every other game where you chase a world-ending villain and his/her catastrophes? Yep. Still fun.While, at this point, the graphics are a little outdated, you occasionally see something jaw dropping in Mass Effect. Smoke drifting diagonally away from lava-coated vistas (that you're DRIVING THROUGH) or a blinding, lilac sun on an alien horizon can, once-in-a-while, take your breath away.The dialogue is meticulously thought-out and well acted (while sometimes sounding a LITTLE dry) and it makes for a great dialogue-system where you know what you choose to say can and will have an effect on the outcome of a mission. It's one of the first games I played that implemented this. Although, while you have choices in ME, all those anastamosing plotlines end you up in the same place. That's not a downside (insert a philosophical quote about inevitability and fate here.) You still feel in control of your character and your future though and that's as much as you can ask for in a game.Gameplay-wise, it's fun, if a little simple. There aren't any puzzling moments (unless you count getting temporarily lost in one of the many hubs.) The game repeats a little when you have to play the same fight a few times to win. That's not a criticism. I'm all for old-school, 'git good' gaming.There are really only three or four main things you'll be doing in this game; shooting at and ducking from a wide variety of clever(ish) enemies, wandering around hub areas looking for answers to life's questions (and convincing people to do things), driving around in the MAKO (amazingly fun for something so simple) to explore planets, and zipping around the galaxy map to go do one of the three aforementioned activities.The combat is FUN and simple, but your two AI counterparts are fairly stupid and don't like to use cover like you do, so will get shot ALOT. Ordering them about feels like you're having to baby two other people whilst not dying in a firefight yourself, but you're Commander Shepherd. You can do it.Wandering back and forth in hub worlds like the Citadel is fun for about five minutes as it's all rather pretty, but eventually, talking to one character then running back to talk to another can get a bit boring and you wind up wanting to leap into some action again, which you can't without finishing your conversational wanderings. And prepare for ALOT of elevators. It's M.E.'s way of loading parts of maps while you're travelling but it takes you out of things a bit and they make you use elevators a whole lot. Boring, sadly.Planet exploring is fun and scenic (did I mention this game is beautiful?) especially in the MAKO. The vehicle is fun to drive around, even if it does have some crazy oversteer, but what do you expect when you're on the surface of some low-G moon driving over dunes and dustscapes? The guns feel powerful but don't bother trying to shoot anything near you as the thing can't aim down and the MAKO is quite tall. Just run over the enemies, dammit.They've put so much effort into fleshing out the characters and histories in this game; of you, your squad mates and beyond and it's all well voice acted. You can feel sparks fly not only between you and your teammates, but you notice which squadmates like each other and where rivalries lie in all the tiny ways. And everybody has their flaws. I love Ashley. No denying it there. I love her go-gettem attitude and her out of nowhere attraction to poetry. But she's also super racist against aliens, although she denies it. These aren't character tropes that come out of nowhere. Ashley's lived a life before you knew her and she's willing to tell you about it if you get to know her, from her gung-ho attitude she cultivated with her sister, to her father's love of poetry handed down to her, to her stoic patriotism towards Earth and Humanity leading to her distrust of alien races. Like her or not, she's human (irony intended); so much more than just a 3D rendered cardboard cutout. Now apply that detail to the dozens of characters, locations and races in Mass Effect. (All except Saren, the main villain of the game, who seems to just be a laughing, evil face with no deep backstory other than a foreboding 'he used to be what you are now.') They've sat down and thought this universe out. We NEED more people to do this when making games. It's probably the biggest selling point of Mass Effect. The galaxy has existed long before you arrived and will go on long after you leave (until ME3 maybe). You can ignore all of it; skip past the expositional dialogue or ignore informative text boxes altogether. But if you want the lore, it's all there and it's beautiful. Plus, they make a GOOD attempt at sciencing everything well. It's what makes for 'science-fiction' rather than 'space-fantasy.'So, to sum up:+This game is STILL beautiful after all these years.+The people and locations are so detailed in lore and history that you can't help but love them all. +You feel in control of yourself in a vast universe where everything seems to be going wrong.+The gameplay is fun and simple, and there's a lot of it.+ Hit the jets on the MAKO while driving up a mountain and try to do a backflip!!!- The gameplay can get a little repetitive.- Slightly generic (but forgivable) plotlines, particularly in some side missions.- Ultimately, you're choices don't change the ultimate outcome of the game, but it shows how small you are in this huge story anyway, and serves to drive home that point. (So, secretly a positive?)The negatives are small and are hugely outweighed by the positives.9/10.*Cue opening thematic music***Doooooo dooo doooooooooo doooooo**

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Initial impression:10/10I've held this one aside for too long... "breathtaking, magnificent and absolutely magnetic in game-play"Time:39h odd for all the secondary content and some serious running in circles. (I found the 'minimum' minerals needed for one assignment, finding more doesn't matter and is never spoken of. otherwise 100%)bad points:Optimisation is very poor, I've turned a lot of the settings down to fix: After an hour or so the game GRINDS TO A HALT and the sounds get chewed up. I'm really not happy with this. (I can run the sequel without problems)This game feels like an "Elevator Simulator" ... (please tag product)-I mean SERIOUSLY want to know what it's like to stand in an elevator for 8 or 10 seconds EVERY 2 mins??? ... I've added a user interface command to selectively fast-forward its THAT BAD!The off-roader (MAKO) is pretty twitchy, and uncontrollable like it only wants to point N, NE, E... rather than steer in smooth circles plus it gets thrown about a lot with the exploration (off-world).Exploring other worlds with the Mako is a slow slow frustrating process, again thank goodness for the fast forward.Trying to walk on mountainous terrain: slow, the characters get stuck or simply can't climb anything that looks like a hill, failing that falling through the floor is a serious risk... This has happened rather a lot!There are a few long 'driving' sections which are a complete waste of time/game-play, I think the maps (both off-world and the driving sections) need an overhaul.I think the game moved a little too fast... Shepard seems to overnight gain the keys to the GALAXY... Makes me wonder exactly what did happen on Eden Prime????After 22h.... I'm sadden to say I feel almost ready for the story to wrap up. While the cites are just amazing the exploration off-world has too much obvious "recycling" ... It feels like fan-art or a mod!and it just doesn't bloody stop, pointless 'side-mission' after pointless 'side-mission'I few more story missions recouped my enthusiasm for the game, but not a replay yet... but I do have the sequel lined up.Overall I give this game 8.5/10 (recall my non-linear scoring system)

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
One of the best modern story-driven RPG's I've ever played. I have no complaints about ME1. I loved every minute of my 2 playthroughs. On my 5yr old PC there were no graphic glitches, no lag or issues of any kind. Just smooth sailing graphics & a wonderful story. The characters are well-written, even the ones you don't like (looking at you Ashley). As in KOTOR, you can go Light or Dark, good or bad, making Dialog choices to reflect your own personality or how you want Commander Shepard to be perceived. In this game at least, your choices don't really affect the endgame outcome. Your choices DO open up different dialog options and some side quests. It adds fun flavor to the game.I loved finding all the armor & weps scattered around everywhere you go. I liked the hacking puzzle mini-game to open caches. It reminded me of the similar hydraulic puzzle game in Bioshock, which I also loved - both the main game & the mini puzzle game.The DLC is FreeAnother plus for ME1 is the 2 DLC's are free & easily found to download. Some nice people have already linked them in other helpful reviews, or just Google.Common ComplaintsThe MakoSome people complain about the Mako, which if you haven't played the game yet, is a tank-like vehicle you drive when you explore planets. I personally loved driving the crazy thing. Yes, it can be hard to control. Things can get a little wild, but it's really not that hard & once you get the hang of it, driving it literally anywhere is good fun. Mostly though, combat in the thing with its cannon & gun are a literal blast.ExplorationSome people complained about exploring Planets. I personally enjoyed this aspect as well. You only explore at most, 1 planet per system, & exploring each planet only takes a few minutes. Of course, I did really like driving the Mako so any excuse to get in the thing & go nuts was welcome.Game Won't Start, or get a Black or White Screen then game won't startThis did actually happen to me once, but is VERY simple to fix. Find the game's .exe, right click it and select "Open as Administrator". If that doesn't work for you, exit Steam, then Right-click Steam to "Open As", THEN rt click ME1's .exe to "Open As". You should only ever have to do this once, then done. It happened to me at about 5hours in. I was frustrated for about 10 minutes before I found this simple solution. After that I just started the game normally for the rest of my playtime.Other Similar Games I recommend you play:Dragon Age SeriesMass Effect SeriesKOTOR SeriesBioshock Series - Especially 1, 2 & Minerva's Den DLC (Excellent standalone story there)All of those game titles are equal in my esteem. They all provide good value for the price & all have a great story. These games all really draw you in. IMO you just can't go wrong with any of them.Comments About ME2 & 3(*Included here because many people are buying 1&2 here together)While ME1 had only 2 DLC, both of which are now free, ME2 & ME3 both have numerous expensive DLC that never goes on sale. In fact, you can't just "buy" & DL DLC for those 2 games. Nope. Even though you can purchase ME2 on Steam, you have to go to Origin to get the DLC for it.Of course some people needlessly complain about Origin, but truthfully, Origin is awesome. It's a very solid Game Management / Store Interface, just as good as Steam for it's own purposes.Anyway, say you buy the ME1/2 pack here on Steam & you want to then buy DLC for the game, which must be done on Origin (or also on social.bioware.com). ME2/Deluxe does come with a tiny bit of DLC, which you can also activate on Origin along with the base game, should you wish to. Simple steps are needed: Install the game in Steam Right-click ME2 in your Steam library and "View CD Key" (The game must be installed to have this option) Open Origin. If you didn't already, create an account & log in. At the top left, click on Origin, then click "Redeem Product Code" There are 3 codes for ME2. Copy each from the little Steam window, one at a time, then paste to Activate in the Origin app. Find the game in your Origin Library, hover the mouse over it then click the little italicized "i", which opens a more detailed Information page.On the Info page you can see a list of all the DLC, much of which is free. However, the good stuff, namely the Content packs which give you more missions & not just fluff cosmetics, cost money.Actually, they cost "Bioware Points". Yes, it's lame, but there's no way around it. BC although Bioware makes insanely awesome games, the guy in charge of setting up the sale of DLC is obviously a crackhead. There's simply no other explanation for why they think this is a good idea, as opposed to just being able to put all the desired DLC in your cart then buying it all straight up.Nope. You put what you want in the cart, then when you Checkout......it takes you to buy Bioware Points. 1600 Points sells for $20, 1200/$15 & 800/$10. It's very simple math to figure out which DLC you really want then convert the dollar value to how many Bioware Points you need. It's really very annoying, but it's not that complicated.You're going to need ~$40 for all the ME2 DLC. More for ME3. So, even though you probably only paid $20 for all 3 games (on sale of course), you're going to probably be forking out $80+ more dollars for any content & cosmetics you may want for ME2 & ME3.One last note. I hear that DLC you buy for ME2 (in Origin of course) can also be activated in your Steam copy of the game, though I don't see the need to do it, so I've never tried. I honeslty don't know why you wouldn't just play it in Origin. But it's said to be possible should you wish to try it.Hope this info was helpful. Enjoy!

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												What can I say about Mass Effect? It is one of my all-time favorite games. The story is really good and the replay value is high due to the fact that you can create different characters focusing on different abilities. Want to be a soldier with all the toys of destruction or a full biotic with limited weapons, or a technician. You can play a character as these types and some in between.One of the greatest things about the Mass Effect trilogy is that you can import a completed game character into the next installment of the franchise and get bonuses for completing the last installment and pick your character up where you left off. You of course can always just start a new character as well, but it is the carryover of the character that makes the series really unique.The only strikes against it is some of the tedium related to exploring planets and inventory wrangling.Definitely a must buy.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I've finally got around to beginning the Mass Effect series, and numero uno was a blast. An incredibly immersive, well crafted and believable universe, I found myself happily getting lost in the cultural depth and history created here, of the Geth, Krogan, Turian, Rachni and more. Mass Effect features a wide range of well written, memorable characters (Liara, Wrex, Garrus, Saren, Anderson, Sovereign, could go on), some great clever dialogue and many funny moments, as well as more painful ones as the consequences of your actions play out through the story. One of the best aspects of the game as you progress is simply getting to know your crewmates that you're choosing to work with mission by mission. The music is fantastic, and acts beautifully to create atmosphere and in binding all the various parts of the game together (Vigil, Galaxy Map theme i'm looking at you). For a title released in 2007/2008 the graphics seem to have endured really well, and again fit perfectly with the overall feel of the game. While you're exploring planets be sure to stop and take a few seconds at the summit of a mountain and look out at the vista before you, it's pretty damn gorgeous. Gameplay wise, combat is fun and pretty well balanced, if a little on the easy side. I found biotic abilities particularly enjoyable, there's also a lot of room to customise gear and weapons as you see fit, especially later in the game. Movement is kept varied in space or on land, between exploring new worlds/buildings on foot or by roaming and driving up sheer cliffs in the Mako, hopping around the interior of the Normandy and navigating the Galaxy Map, there is a real and epic sense of scale here (Moon landing included), and the freedom to seek it out.The only slight cons I can think of are somewhat repetitive sidequests; with a bouncy tin tank that has some infamous clunky manoeuvring, and slowpoke elevators (which excellent dialogue and hilarious music almost make up for). The inventory can become a bit tricky to manage. Worlds explored outside of main quests could also be more detailed and fleshed out in terms of content beyond markers on the map. Summary: A brilliant and deeply satisfying narrative experience overall, and I will be coming back for more playthroughs after visiting the next installments of Mass Effect. Just play it.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The game that started one of the biggest sci-fi adventures in gaming history. It's got everything required to make it a classic; interesting and fun characters with unique cultures,  philospohical questions and moral dilemmas, all wrapped around a well-paced and intriguing story (in my opinion the best in the series). It is a wonderful universe that is really easy to get into, though there are a couple of hurdles that really need to be overcome to get a truly great experience out of this. Throughout a lot of the game, characters will spend a LOT of time explaining things to you, like how cultures work and such.  The story, as I mentioned earlier is great, but the gameplay is not. Combat is fairly clunky, cover system is awkward, every gun feels the same, a lot of enemies are braindead and just run up to you with no regard for their own personal safety. Not exactly the highlight of the game, to put it mildly. The Mako, the vehicle which you use for explo-ration as well as a lot of missions, isn't much better either. It's awkward, handles very poorly and is very boring in use for combat, it's generally used for padding outgame length. Still, it is all in all an amazing game, and gets a 9.1/10 from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Mass Effect has always been on the top of my "recommended" list. I really enjoy single-player RPGs in general, especially those with compelling story lines. Considering how hyped these games are, I had high expectations after I bought the game and sat down to play it. From the get-go, I loved how the game's action was designed with a strong emphasis on gear and squadmates, and a smaller emphasis on combat, which was generally very easy on normal difficulty (and honestly it wasn't that challenging on hard). The decisions, however, were far from easy. I'll avoid spoilers, but Sheperd's decisions can mean life or death for some members of the crew, which you grow attached to throughout the campaign. Mass Effect is all about role-playing and it does it very well. If you don't feel emotionally invested in Sheperd and his crew, you're playing the game wrong. It's not so much the gameplay (which is still pretty good), but the emotion and ability to make the story your own that makes it a really good game. I'll definitely be playing the sequel soon. 8.75/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game sets up a very rich and deep universe with lots of unique dialogue and text (logs) to read which make the game feel a LOT bigger than it actually is. The main story in the sequels might be longer and intense but they don't evoke the feeling of being in a massive universe like this one does.Gameplay wise, it's a bit lacking to be honest - the dialogue choices can be really misleading at times, the combat hasn't aged well and the levels feel a bit sterile or even stale (ex. planetary exploration) at times. Mass Effect 2 might have fixed these issues but at the cost of the more deeper RPG elements of this one.The sense of scale and all the little story elements that are hidden in Mass Effect make it a great game, well worth replaying even a few years after release, even knowing it all amounts to nothing (ME3)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												I just finished beating this game, I'm a little late to get into this series I think, but regardless, I bought it and played it.And well I can honestly say I don't regret a dollar or a minute spent on this. This game is just awesome.Where do I start...First of all the game looks pretty good, even if its a bit older. I don't have a computer that can play on the highest settings honestly, but I still found it enjoyable and looked pretty clean to me. Regardless I don't really care that much to be honest ;pOh and the combat is pretty enjoyable I find. Its a shooter type of combat basically, but with a few RPG elements to the combat, I find it quite enjoyable personally, the number of ablities are not overly abundant, but I'm ok with that. I find it doesn't bother me a ton. The combat was also pretty well made so that you, in most cases, can't just go in the middle of the fight, and you actually have to take cover and stuff. It was pretty decently challanging at times and I was playing on the normal difficulty or default one or whatever. Maybe I just suck, idk ;p. But it typically doesn't feel to easy. The part about the game that is arguably the best however is the story, and the interacting with characters, its hard to pick one, but they sort of go hand in hand to an extent.I won't spoil the story to those who haven't played, but I found it very good, it felt like I was watching a movie and I was always curious as to what would happen next, or in the future. As for the interaction with other characters, especially squad members, it is just very interesting. In talking to the different crew members you learn more about them, and sometimes about different species, and you even learn about other background information and their personal thoughts on things. Not to mention sometimes get missions. You can also romance with any squad member of the opposite gender if you so choose ;p. Oh and you can loose squad members(I lost two in my playthrough) which sounds bad, but it only happens through story events. Some are unpreventable to my knowledge, and they lead to some hard choices, which can really play with your emotions and make you feel guilty.Overall the game does a great job of getting you attached(Or to hate) the different characters, and that is just really enjoyable. However the game isn't without its flaws. First of all the game I noticed had a fair number of bugs, some minor, others frusterating, and some making it so I had to reload the game. I only encountered maybe 5 in my whole playthrough, but I think 3 of them involved me falling through the world and having to reload the game, which was frustating at times. There is also a weird black siloute bug that apparently involves AMD processors or something, look it up, I did and apparently others with AMD processors and stuff have similar issues, not unplayable with it, and it only occurs in like two different worlds in the main story, but it can be a bit annoying. Another thing I noticed is that atleast concerning the classes that don't specialize in using the sniper there is no scope, its like a blind fire weapon basically and totally useless. Of course I haven't played anything besides sentinel, so it could be different on them. Frankly the weapons besides the pistol that I had a specialization in on my class where kinda useless I found and I never used any much besides the pistol and sometimes the shotgun, but thats really not that big of a deal, the sniper ones really the biggest issue concerning the weapons. Overall the game is great, it has me hooked after playing through it once, and contemplating playing again, so i'd say its well worth it. I'm going to go after the next games in the series as soon as I can.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												PROS:+ Definitely one of the most interesting, yet complex plots out there+ Gameplay is dynamically shaped by your actions and dialogue selections+ Can go around as a total♥♥♥♥♥♥ or an ethical and universal role model+ Epic protagonist+ Fluid game mechanics+ Does a decent job getting your emotions a little worked up+ Viable for replayability+ Most maps are impressively immersive+ AI is actually pretty good+ Different alien species can be fun to learn more about+ Gives the player the option to play strategically with the eccentric specialties of each squad member+ Fun side quests, with some being humorous+ Even after understanding the plot 100%, there are still unresolvable mysteries that leave the players to assume for themselves+ Awesome voice acting, but Shepard's can start to sound monotone after a while+ Textures are a little meh, but are enough to keep you immersed+ Lotsa lens flares+ Optional and unintrusive romanceCONS:- Citadel is large and can be too confusing to navigate through- Too many useless elevators- Walking/jogging speed is kind of slow- Inventory system is really annoying to use- Sound sometimes, but rarely, started acting whacky for me- Exploring ("landing on") planets that are extraneous to the main plot can sometimes be rewarding, but are mostly "cookie cutter'ed"- Music is very sci-fi'y, but sometimes annoyed me due to the short loops- Gun model variation is pretty unexciting (maybe 2 models per type, with about 3 colors per model)- No free-roam after completing game, so make sure you do all the side-quests you're interested in and explore BEORE you begin the final quest

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												The first thing that comes to mind when I think of Mass Effect is the thoroughness in how well thought out the universe is. The science - what's explained anyway - sounds interesting and plausible (not that I would really know). The concept of labeling any species as "goodguys" or "badguys" is hard to do since there are handfulls of both good and bad for each one (can't quite call any Hannar "bad" but no point nitpicking).The second thing I noticed was the story was really compelling in a way that felt more involving than other games. Think of Mass Effect as a videogame version of a "Choose Your Own Adventure" book. The choices you make can affect huge storylines that span the entire series. Sadly giving examples would spoil them. You can even unlock special actions/comments by raising meters gauging your Paragon and Renegade levels. That said almost every single active side quest was pretty repetitive. Go to planet. Drive on planet. Go in only building on planet. Kill a group of people. Collect loot.The combat is fun. How hard it is almost entirely depends on how well you are equipped. If you and your squad aren't equipped then you'll die sometimes. If they're well equipped most missions will typically be manageable on your first attempts. It might have been easier for me being I was an Engineer on my playthrough though - I destroyed shields and overheated weapons and hacked synthetic enemies to control the crowd a bit. I'm eager to try the game again as another class to see how different it would be.The driving parts with the Mako tank sometimes felt out of place. There were a few times it was major fun to drive. The missions involved obviously intended for the tank - like when driving it in the roofs of the ruins of skyscrapers - were awesome. However almost every planet you go to involves dropping onto the surface with the Mako tank before you drive around to check all the marked spots on a map (technically you could ignore them, but this is the most major way to run acrossed large money and some side-mission peices - which also possibly affect things later in the series). A lot of these worlds were mountainous and would make the Mako tank feel pretty mind numbingly slow on the incline.The inventory system was a mess. You could only hold so many items at a time and these items fill up fast on missions - between times you manage to run into a shop to unload them. This means you end up having to mess with it constantly. It's barely sorted in any way and it randomizes the entire list when you equip anything - making it a pain to find what you look for. It at least only shows items that fit in whatever slot you were trying to equip.The graphics were better than I expected them to be for a 10 year old game. Felt like what I usually have them set at for today's games.This game honestly feels like it should be added to some list of "Games Every Gamer Ought to Play." It feels like I'm playing a legend. Might have been because I've heard it's good for about 10 years.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Pros:-Story. This isn't surprising. Bioware games tend to be very plot-heavy and less centered on action. More talky-talky bits and extreme decision making. Less shooty-killy.The downside is that while you get a good chunk of the story in the beginning, it doesn't really pick up fully until over halfway through the game.Don't get me wrong. When it picks up, it really picks you up and throws you over the table and repeatedly screws you.-Decisions. Like in Dragon Age, the choices you make do effect the rest of the gameplay and subsequent events. Impacting in the next two games for the trilogy, though I've yet to play 'em.-Action. My first rpg shooter. I like that it wasn't so centered on kill-kill-kill. It allowed me time to get into it, and I'm not big on shooters. This doesn't feel like it's utterly in my face. It's third-person shooter, so I think that helps.-Controls. Very easy to get used to.-Gameplay. Very few timed events. Cons:-Controls. Yes, this is a pro, but in a few cases, it's a con. And it's only a con when you're in a vehicle called the Mako. Mass Effect was a game designed for the console, not the PC. And it shows. Holy hell, does it show.My driving is akin to a drunkard on speed. I managed to flip the damn car over when gravity was on MY side. Every death I suffered was due to that damn car. And you need to use that car a lot. It kills a lot of the fun within the game. Thankfully, it's not essential to the overall game, and if you're not a completionist, you won't have to use it that often.-The 'lockpicking'. It took me forever to figure out wtf I was supposed to do. The game offers you no direction on that. And in decrypting something, the codes are a bit iffy as opposed to how it is for the xbox or PS3. It's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Once you learn what the hell to do, it's pretty simple. But until you figure it out, it's just banging your head against the wall.-Characters need more by way of development. What was there was definitely touching, and I'm in NO way saying that these characters aren't awesome in their own right. I was touched by a few of their stories. But perhaps I'm spoiled by DA, and Bioware is pretty known for their character development, interactions, etc. -Romances. One male romance for a female main character. One female romance for a male main character. And one female romance for either gender main character.Though I'll give it points for having the bisexual love interest be an alien. Awesome points:-The aliens. Lots of variations, and I really like 'em all. Humans are pretty much on the lower rung here. There are prejudices, other alien races don't much care for humans and humans are the minorities. There's a small group of humans that are all Human Pride sort of thing, but they're largely irrelevant.-The Reapers. I don't want to give any spoilers here, but these are seriously such a badass group of villains. The game made them genuinely scary.-The planets. This probably won't mean much to those who don't care about lore or anything like that, but I found the short summarizations on the different planets to be pretty damn cool and innovative. The Ugly:-The profiles. You cannot make a pretty male Shepherd or a pretty female Shepherd. The textures, lights, shadows, angles will make even the most meticulously done Shepherd fugly. It's highly annoying.-This is one of those games in which it's hard to figure out the first time you play it. Not controls-wise, but everything else-wise. Where to go, what to see, etc. Largely because this world is so big. It's a solar system and it FEELS like a solar system.However, once you've completed one playthrough, you won't really need a guide anymore. It helps that it's a pretty short game. It could probably be played through in the course of a weekend.

												What can I say about Mass Effect? It is one of my all-time favorite games. The story is really good and the replay value is high due to the fact that you can create different characters focusing on different abilities. Want to be a soldier with all the toys of destruction or a full biotic with limited weapons, or a technician. You can play a character as these types and some in between.One of the greatest things about the Mass Effect trilogy is that you can import a completed game character into the next installment of the franchise and get bonuses for completing the last installment and pick your character up where you left off. You of course can always just start a new character as well, but it is the carryover of the character that makes the series really unique.The only strikes against it is some of the tedium related to exploring planets and inventory wrangling.Definitely a must buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												After 3 years of owning this game I finally buckled down and finished it, and man am i glad i did. I was initally hooked by the tight gameplay. This is a very story focused game so the majority of gameplay is very well designed dialogue trees punctuated by cover shooting. The dialogue trees a very intuitive: options that lead to exposition tend to be on the left and  and story advancing, and affecting choices tend to be on the right. The shooting mechanics are pretty simple, but passably enjoyable with the inclusion of biotic powers to add some stratagy to shake things up a bit.As for the story of the game it is fantastic. The setting is a galactic community very reminicent of Star Wars with engaging intergalactic politics reminicent of the best of Star Trek & Babylon 5. In short an amazing sci-fi universe. What i like most in a story is the characters, and Mass Effect has some fantastic characters. My favorites being Liara, Garrus, Wrex, Joker, Captain Anderson, Tali'Zora, and of course Wrex. You may have noticed I just listed most of the potental party members and some of the side characters that is how likable and well written Mass Effect's characters are.Long story short if you are at all a fan of RPGs (this is one of the best i felt fully immersed in the role I was playing), Sci-Fi (the game's universe is the perfect amalgamation of the best of popular Sci-Fi), or even simply great storytelling: Mass Effect comes highly reccommended from me.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Admittedly, when I started playing this game, I didn't have high hopes for it. In a wide galaxy, you play as a human named Shepard, who saves the galaxy and either makes everyone feel bad about how awful they are, or punches everyone in the face. Either way, it's a win/win situation.It's region based open world, which means a lot of the time you will be running around the map trying to find a fast travel spot, but that's the fun part. You get to see a LOT of planets, drive a Mako (probably flip it and be unable to get up a mountain with it), and have aliens join your entourage. As the first game in the franchise, the graphics leave a little to be desired, but it makes up for that with it's combat, storyline, and heartbreaking decisions.All in all, Mass Effect is one of my favorite games, and it's always nice to return to the foundation of the series and make a new Shepard, new choices, and find a new love interest.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Mass Effect is not a sandbox/open-world RPG.  This game is not about shooting things because you can.  This game, is above that.  This game plays a psychological role in your life, depending on whether you allow it to or not.  If it is to be held as an open-world RPG, let the world be the minds of each person you meet, whether for the first time or the last.  Personally, I believe this is more of an RPG than TES or Fallout, as the role you play shows an impact on the world around you, and the decisions you make can decide whether or not you live as a role-model of humanity or a menace that holds importance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Great game. Great universe. Above all, I applaud the dialogue wheel options. Questions I was asking myself were listed which made conversations feel natural, and and the game didn't use Charm or Intimidate skill to resolve most of its story. I'm usually set on what choices my character would make in an RPG, but I actually took a step back a few times to think of the consequences of my actions. Really makes me want to play the game a few more times to see how other choices will affect the game.I'm not a huge fan of dynamic leveling in games especially RPGs where progression matters, but I wish they had added it to this game. When they offer you a universe to quest through it's very easy to make mistakes. One of your first quest options when you get your ship is to find Liara between several planets in a system. The first planet I searched ended up being for level 30's while I was only level 8. I kept dying and I thought I was playing the game wrong because I was new and it took almost two hours to finish it before I found out it was a separate optional quest. Romances felt forced. It seemed as if BioWare tried to use romance as a selling point of the game or something. Although it's kinda acceptable with the way your character interacts with everyone but it was still too blunt. I talked to Ashley once about her history and suddenly she's fighting with Liara over who I love more. It only happened because Ashley herself told me to talk to Liara after her mother dies and Liara suddenly falls in love with me. It seemed unnecessary.Other than those small grievances, the game was great and I'm looking forward to playing the 2nd and 3rd games. Amazed it took me this long to play it.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Great game. If you like RPGs, then you'll love this game. I only played ME3 before I played any other Mass Effect games, and this one has proved why its a must have in only 8 hours of play. Pros:-Runs well on my system (i5 3570k GTX 770) its a 6 year old game so I think I'd be right to assume that it should rune fine on most systems -has extensive dialogue options -Interesting plot-Good graphics for the time-Characters are interesting-The ambiance of locations really make the game feel alive! For example, the Citadel. -The gameplay is fun, and not very conky-I find that the cover system is a lot more advanced than the ones that are offered in other AAA games released today, its pretty adaptive. Cons: -The inventory system isn't all that great-Sometimes there's a bit of screen tearing -If you don't like RPGs and don't really care much about lore and are looking for an fps, then this game won't really stand out for you. Overall, its a great game, and it never hurts to pick it up on a sale and try it. You will most probably enjoy it! 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												When I first heard about Mass Effect, I was quite skeptical on how good it could really be. It is with great honor that I deem my previous thoughts unworthy. Mass Effect is the first of a trilogy, and it holds the rank as being one of the greats. However, tedious inventory management, dated graphics, and planet exploration on a space car that handles badly, are some of the downsides, but put those aside, and there is a great story with great characters awaiting. The story begins with Commander Shepard going on a mission to be tested to be a Spectre, but things go awry, as repected Spectre Saren goes rogue, and things don't go according to plan. Now Shepard must save the galaxy from Saren and his synthetic partners from an ancient evil altogether. Characters are varied, with humans mixed along with some aliens in Commander Shepard's squad. Weapons and armor are numerous, with also mods to put on the armor and weapons. All in all, a great sci-fi RPG that has to be played.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												The first two times I played this game, it was on the lowly XBox 360.  The game was already very dated five years ago, or so it seemed.  My third playthrough, and my first on the PC, and I'm seeing stunning visuals and textures that were simply not present on the console version.  The game looks worlds better than I remember.  Controls are better (except for the vehicle), and it helps to have a deep understanding of game mechanics from playing all three multiple times through.  My first playthrough of this game was frustratingly difficult because I didn't understand what type of character I had picked or how to properly use the powers.  I suggest a revisit to this game for anyone who liked this series.  Tip:  If anyone's having trouble running this game, or using Steam overlay while playing, close Steam, and reopen it as Administrator.  The games will inherit the permissions, and everything will work fine. Tip 2:  For anyone having trouble with resolution settings, dig into the Steam game folder for Mass Effect.  There's a launcher in there that lets you change settings, including increasing resolution (for me, 2560 x 1600, but anything 16:10 will need to be set via this launcher to look correct, because the game will only show 16:9 resolutions while looking at in-game settings.)
