number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												I just finished beating this game, I'm a little late to get into this series I think, but regardless, I bought it and played it.And well I can honestly say I don't regret a dollar or a minute spent on this. This game is just awesome.Where do I start...First of all the game looks pretty good, even if its a bit older. I don't have a computer that can play on the highest settings honestly, but I still found it enjoyable and looked pretty clean to me. Regardless I don't really care that much to be honest ;pOh and the combat is pretty enjoyable I find. Its a shooter type of combat basically, but with a few RPG elements to the combat, I find it quite enjoyable personally, the number of ablities are not overly abundant, but I'm ok with that. I find it doesn't bother me a ton. The combat was also pretty well made so that you, in most cases, can't just go in the middle of the fight, and you actually have to take cover and stuff. It was pretty decently challanging at times and I was playing on the normal difficulty or default one or whatever. Maybe I just suck, idk ;p. But it typically doesn't feel to easy. The part about the game that is arguably the best however is the story, and the interacting with characters, its hard to pick one, but they sort of go hand in hand to an extent.I won't spoil the story to those who haven't played, but I found it very good, it felt like I was watching a movie and I was always curious as to what would happen next, or in the future. As for the interaction with other characters, especially squad members, it is just very interesting. In talking to the different crew members you learn more about them, and sometimes about different species, and you even learn about other background information and their personal thoughts on things. Not to mention sometimes get missions. You can also romance with any squad member of the opposite gender if you so choose ;p. Oh and you can loose squad members(I lost two in my playthrough) which sounds bad, but it only happens through story events. Some are unpreventable to my knowledge, and they lead to some hard choices, which can really play with your emotions and make you feel guilty.Overall the game does a great job of getting you attached(Or to hate) the different characters, and that is just really enjoyable. However the game isn't without its flaws. First of all the game I noticed had a fair number of bugs, some minor, others frusterating, and some making it so I had to reload the game. I only encountered maybe 5 in my whole playthrough, but I think 3 of them involved me falling through the world and having to reload the game, which was frustating at times. There is also a weird black siloute bug that apparently involves AMD processors or something, look it up, I did and apparently others with AMD processors and stuff have similar issues, not unplayable with it, and it only occurs in like two different worlds in the main story, but it can be a bit annoying. Another thing I noticed is that atleast concerning the classes that don't specialize in using the sniper there is no scope, its like a blind fire weapon basically and totally useless. Of course I haven't played anything besides sentinel, so it could be different on them. Frankly the weapons besides the pistol that I had a specialization in on my class where kinda useless I found and I never used any much besides the pistol and sometimes the shotgun, but thats really not that big of a deal, the sniper ones really the biggest issue concerning the weapons. Overall the game is great, it has me hooked after playing through it once, and contemplating playing again, so i'd say its well worth it. I'm going to go after the next games in the series as soon as I can.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2013
												After bunches of strangers posted to me about Mass Effect, I finally gave it a go. Space-themed game with focus on story? Sounds right up my alley.Right away, I need to criticize the main city of the game, the Citadel. Who in the world designed this mess? I'm not saying it's fugly. In fact, it looks quite nice. It's just that it's poorly laid out and needlessly labyrinthine... especially for a main hub of the game.The shooter aspect was okay. I'm not really a first or third person shooter type, but it worked, and it was playable, so I'll leave it at that.I'm still not exactly sure what the point of scanning planets for resources was. It was hardly crucial to the plot or gameplay. Just a pure homage to Star Control?Replay value is... there. I admit I would have liked to go back and earn some achievements that provide rewards, but the gameplay just wasn't enticing enough to me to warrant a second playthrough. I need to note that playing as a Paragon is boring as hell. I recommend trying out a Renegade to bring out the more interesting conversations.The game has excellent atmosphere, and some pretty interesting alien backstory. I don't quite understand the trend of cramming in bucketloads of irrelevant information in the in-game encyclopedia, but I guess there's an audience for it. The strength of the game I feel is in the character conversations, but those weren't as frequent as I would have liked.Overall I'd have to say I wasn't disappointed. I wasn't blown away by the plot, though that's my fault for setting a high expectation. The main story isn't the kind of story that makes you a better person for having experienced it, but it was interesting nonetheless, especially towards the end. Still not Planescape: Torment caliber. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: September 21, 2013
												If you haven't already purchased this game, you should go and purchase it right now.  Why? Well there's plenty of reasons. Mass Effect is the beginning to the phenomenal trilogy that revolutionized what it means to give a player choice.  In this game you are Shepard, a Commander in the Alliance Navy. Essentially you learn that the rogue Spectre, the galaxy's highest ranking police essentially, Saren is attempting to bring back the ancient machine race known as the Reapers. While tracking Saren down, Shepard meets many valuable teammates, and loses them, based on how you play.The dialogue in this game is centered mostly around a wheel with several parts, each having different types of dialogue choices. Want to attempt to save all the survivors of an attack? Sure. Want to punch the ♥♥♥♥♥y news-reporter in her face? Feel free, it's your choice. Choices, which do carry on the sequels, mind you. While the story and dialogue in the first game entice you to finish it, I do have to admit that the combat is not the best. It's pretty bad, but not too bad that it makes it unbearable to play. But don't worry, the problem is solved in the next game so don't lose hope. There are also a few bugs in the game that annoy you sometimes and also a few graphical errors, but nothing that will keep you from enjoying the masterpiece that is Mass Effect.On a scale of 1 to 10, I would gives Mass Effect a 9.2.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												It is hard to say just how much I love this game (and ME2) This game has everything you could want in an RPG, great story, great people that you come to care about in a small way. The only downside I can think of, is that in order to complete every possible thing you can, you do A LOT of "Moon Patrol" type play. Driving a vehicle on alien planets that are pretty much just bare and offer only small changes from the last naked alien planet you were driving on. You can however complete the game without doing EVERY part, and thus can avoid much of this.The best part of this game is how you can import your character into ME2 and the choices you made have an effect on what happens.My suggestion, if you can, is to start up ME2, and make your toon there first (face) get a code and THEN make it in ME1. Otherwise you import your toon and do not get a code, forcing you to start over making a face. Bad if you get attached to your Shepard, which happens easily.I suggest playing as a female Shepard, no, not (just) because of eye candy, but because I honestly feel that the female voice acting is better, and somehow the Shepard character makes more sense as a woman. Plus when you choose the renegade (badass) options, rather than the goodygoody options, it just makes them sound 100% cooler comming from a woman ^_^.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Great game. Great universe. Above all, I applaud the dialogue wheel options. Questions I was asking myself were listed which made conversations feel natural, and and the game didn't use Charm or Intimidate skill to resolve most of its story. I'm usually set on what choices my character would make in an RPG, but I actually took a step back a few times to think of the consequences of my actions. Really makes me want to play the game a few more times to see how other choices will affect the game.I'm not a huge fan of dynamic leveling in games especially RPGs where progression matters, but I wish they had added it to this game. When they offer you a universe to quest through it's very easy to make mistakes. One of your first quest options when you get your ship is to find Liara between several planets in a system. The first planet I searched ended up being for level 30's while I was only level 8. I kept dying and I thought I was playing the game wrong because I was new and it took almost two hours to finish it before I found out it was a separate optional quest. Romances felt forced. It seemed as if BioWare tried to use romance as a selling point of the game or something. Although it's kinda acceptable with the way your character interacts with everyone but it was still too blunt. I talked to Ashley once about her history and suddenly she's fighting with Liara over who I love more. It only happened because Ashley herself told me to talk to Liara after her mother dies and Liara suddenly falls in love with me. It seemed unnecessary.Other than those small grievances, the game was great and I'm looking forward to playing the 2nd and 3rd games. Amazed it took me this long to play it.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Mass Effect is a story-rich FPS where you play as Shepard, in a time where the universe is starting to realise the potential of the human species in taking up bigger responsibilities alongside others. Initially under Captain Anderson's command, you are tasked to investigate a distress signal on a planet and during which, you discover that a trusted ally is setting something shady into motion. Throughout the game. you hunt him down and discover the secrets that would have implications on everyone in the known universe.The game focuses strongly on the story, during which you would have to make a number of decisions that although may not change the story itself, they translate to your character stats, and also the (remaining) crew that you fight with. (And also your sex life lmao.) The combat system is pretty good in that you fight in a section of 3, where your crew could provide interesting powers or just be meat shields as you recharge your own powerups. However, some hostiles such as snipers or rocket turrets could possibly one-shot Shepard and you would have to restart from where the game last saved. Hence, I do recommend that you consistently manual save or you might have to replay a large part of the mission.I find the game very well-rounded and enjoyable, back by an interesting story. However, one major set back to the action for me would be the extremely long elevator rides. Seems silly but you would have to play it to understand the agony :)9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												590 hours.  Thats 24 unblinking, unsleeping days with the crew of the Normandy.According to the combined statistics of Steam, and Origin. Over a hundred fourty hours went into the original Mass Effect (four playthroughs), 289 hours into Mass Effect 2 (six playthroughs), and 219 hours into Mass Effect 3 (two compleate playthroughs, many incompleate) and 8 hours into ME4 Andromeda.Commander Shepard and her crew(no one should play as male Shep imho), have done plenty of galaxy saving, and stirring up,  under my control. They fought, robots, clones, politicians, and reporters. They made love to aliens, hate to aliens, and even saved a race from going compleatly extinct!  We laughed, cried, got wasted, and most importantly fought beside one another through thick and thin.They're my friends.OK, they're not really my friends; claiming to be buddies with imaginary characters is a little too geeky even for me. The Mass Effect series is not without its flaws, and some are truly Reaper-sized. But it has gripped me like nothing else in the history of video games, and video games and I go back a pretty long way (but I'll never betoo old for video games)!The Mass Effect universe is that rare thing—a fully-realized science fiction game setting that stands up to the likes of Star Trek or Star Wars. The universe in which the games take place has a rich and complex backstory, and even better, it's not a rich and complex back story that the player has to have info-dumped into his head. This isn't The Old Republic, where you have to read thousands of awful Kevin J. Anderson "Extended Universe" novels and have a working knowledge of the seven prime forms of lightsaber combat to get the most out of the game.There's depth in the backstory, but it's not the kind of depth that ever compelled me to memorize the game's codex entries. (Do you really need to know that the "First Contact War" between humans and Turians started because humans activated a mass relay in violation of council law and that the war culminated in the siege of Shanxi? No. It's wonderful flavor, but it's not mandatory knowledge.) The world is alive and compellingly real just through dialogue and character actions, without needing endless narration. The first game's opening title crawl essentially says, "This is the future and aliens are real and you are a space soldier. Go." That's enough.Instead of a galactic civics lesson, Mass Effect focuses on a human, the forever-first-nameless Commander Shepard, and her fight against the ancient Reapers, an enemy that aims to rid the galaxy of advanced sentient life for a whole bunch of really complicated reasons. That fight is the central focus of all three games, though Shepard's path from soldier to savior twists and turns and doubles back on itself like a demented snake.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												It is hard to say just how much I love this game (and ME2) This game has everything you could want in an RPG, great story, great people that you come to care about in a small way. The only downside I can think of, is that in order to complete every possible thing you can, you do A LOT of "Moon Patrol" type play. Driving a vehicle on alien planets that are pretty much just bare and offer only small changes from the last naked alien planet you were driving on. You can however complete the game without doing EVERY part, and thus can avoid much of this.The best part of this game is how you can import your character into ME2 and the choices you made have an effect on what happens.My suggestion, if you can, is to start up ME2, and make your toon there first (face) get a code and THEN make it in ME1. Otherwise you import your toon and do not get a code, forcing you to start over making a face. Bad if you get attached to your Shepard, which happens easily.I suggest playing as a female Shepard, no, not (just) because of eye candy, but because I honestly feel that the female voice acting is better, and somehow the Shepard character makes more sense as a woman. Plus when you choose the renegade (badass) options, rather than the goodygoody options, it just makes them sound 100% cooler comming from a woman ^_^.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2011
												This is one of those games that people seem to either love or just like.  I have never found anyone who hated it.  I am firmly in the "love" category.  One of those singleplayer experiences that you will remember forever.  Also, another one of the rare games that I find myself coming back to over and over again.  Like Deus Ex, it is basically a shooter with RPG elements (a TPS instead of an FPS).  Also like Deus Ex, you will find that there are often choices that you face in campaign that will change the gameplay and direction of the rest of the game.  Mass Effect has a perfect balance of choice, action, customizing, freedom, and intrigue to keep you coming back over and over again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Mass Effect is an amazing game.I first played it years ago when I was a young teenager,  when it was the only ME game out there and it shaped what I expected of gaming from then on. Everything from the atmosphere of the game (the music in particular is something to behold) to the narrative and how it plays out all feels well thought-out and engaging. Some of the plot and side-missions feel like they're plucked from generic sci-fi plotlines and remuddled a bit, but in ME's own way, it owns those factors and you no longer think "That whole alien queen speaking telepathically to someone has been done before" and rather think "Mass Effect did it and did it well." Your rampage across the galaxy to find this villain who's become a harbinger for the end of life as we know it is fun, and you care about it. Is it the same as every other game where you chase a world-ending villain and his/her catastrophes? Yep. Still fun.While, at this point, the graphics are a little outdated, you occasionally see something jaw dropping in Mass Effect. Smoke drifting diagonally away from lava-coated vistas (that you're DRIVING THROUGH) or a blinding, lilac sun on an alien horizon can, once-in-a-while, take your breath away.The dialogue is meticulously thought-out and well acted (while sometimes sounding a LITTLE dry) and it makes for a great dialogue-system where you know what you choose to say can and will have an effect on the outcome of a mission. It's one of the first games I played that implemented this. Although, while you have choices in ME, all those anastamosing plotlines end you up in the same place. That's not a downside (insert a philosophical quote about inevitability and fate here.) You still feel in control of your character and your future though and that's as much as you can ask for in a game.Gameplay-wise, it's fun, if a little simple. There aren't any puzzling moments (unless you count getting temporarily lost in one of the many hubs.) The game repeats a little when you have to play the same fight a few times to win. That's not a criticism. I'm all for old-school, 'git good' gaming.There are really only three or four main things you'll be doing in this game; shooting at and ducking from a wide variety of clever(ish) enemies, wandering around hub areas looking for answers to life's questions (and convincing people to do things), driving around in the MAKO (amazingly fun for something so simple) to explore planets, and zipping around the galaxy map to go do one of the three aforementioned activities.The combat is FUN and simple, but your two AI counterparts are fairly stupid and don't like to use cover like you do, so will get shot ALOT. Ordering them about feels like you're having to baby two other people whilst not dying in a firefight yourself, but you're Commander Shepherd. You can do it.Wandering back and forth in hub worlds like the Citadel is fun for about five minutes as it's all rather pretty, but eventually, talking to one character then running back to talk to another can get a bit boring and you wind up wanting to leap into some action again, which you can't without finishing your conversational wanderings. And prepare for ALOT of elevators. It's M.E.'s way of loading parts of maps while you're travelling but it takes you out of things a bit and they make you use elevators a whole lot. Boring, sadly.Planet exploring is fun and scenic (did I mention this game is beautiful?) especially in the MAKO. The vehicle is fun to drive around, even if it does have some crazy oversteer, but what do you expect when you're on the surface of some low-G moon driving over dunes and dustscapes? The guns feel powerful but don't bother trying to shoot anything near you as the thing can't aim down and the MAKO is quite tall. Just run over the enemies, dammit.They've put so much effort into fleshing out the characters and histories in this game; of you, your squad mates and beyond and it's all well voice acted. You can feel sparks fly not only between you and your teammates, but you notice which squadmates like each other and where rivalries lie in all the tiny ways. And everybody has their flaws. I love Ashley. No denying it there. I love her go-gettem attitude and her out of nowhere attraction to poetry. But she's also super racist against aliens, although she denies it. These aren't character tropes that come out of nowhere. Ashley's lived a life before you knew her and she's willing to tell you about it if you get to know her, from her gung-ho attitude she cultivated with her sister, to her father's love of poetry handed down to her, to her stoic patriotism towards Earth and Humanity leading to her distrust of alien races. Like her or not, she's human (irony intended); so much more than just a 3D rendered cardboard cutout. Now apply that detail to the dozens of characters, locations and races in Mass Effect. (All except Saren, the main villain of the game, who seems to just be a laughing, evil face with no deep backstory other than a foreboding 'he used to be what you are now.') They've sat down and thought this universe out. We NEED more people to do this when making games. It's probably the biggest selling point of Mass Effect. The galaxy has existed long before you arrived and will go on long after you leave (until ME3 maybe). You can ignore all of it; skip past the expositional dialogue or ignore informative text boxes altogether. But if you want the lore, it's all there and it's beautiful. Plus, they make a GOOD attempt at sciencing everything well. It's what makes for 'science-fiction' rather than 'space-fantasy.'So, to sum up:+This game is STILL beautiful after all these years.+The people and locations are so detailed in lore and history that you can't help but love them all. +You feel in control of yourself in a vast universe where everything seems to be going wrong.+The gameplay is fun and simple, and there's a lot of it.+ Hit the jets on the MAKO while driving up a mountain and try to do a backflip!!!- The gameplay can get a little repetitive.- Slightly generic (but forgivable) plotlines, particularly in some side missions.- Ultimately, you're choices don't change the ultimate outcome of the game, but it shows how small you are in this huge story anyway, and serves to drive home that point. (So, secretly a positive?)The negatives are small and are hugely outweighed by the positives.9/10.*Cue opening thematic music***Doooooo dooo doooooooooo doooooo**

content:
Posted: March 7, 2011
												OK! Seriously, you should get this phenomonal game, it's WELL worth the price tag of $20! It's a 3rd person shooter which features fleshed out characters and long cinematic cutscenes, superbly intertwined to form a vast universe of which no other game has come closer to creating. Its an RPG which means levelling-up, but there's no need to level grind in any area of the game, as levels get you added bonuses which may give you a slight edge. There is also a customisable weapons feature, where you can modify rounds and parts of your guns.Absolutely perfect, except for the driving sequences (which are few and far between), in which you control a car that handles 'like a fat kid on a unicycle'.9.9/10

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Mass Effect is a great game - some may criticise the combat but I liked it. It's a brilliant example of what an action-RPG should be in terms of interaction and dialogue. There's plenty of background lore to read through, and it's actually quite interesting. The story is also very good, and there are lots of side-quests to pursue as you explore various systems. Unlike other games, there are actual consequences in Mass Effect and your actions can and will decide who lives and who dies.The use of elevators is also a key gameplay mechanic that I find adds a lot to the game.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												So I found Mass Effect on a Steam Sale back in 2013, and purchased it for hardly anything. I'd not read any reviews on the game, so had no idea what to expect once I bought it. I guess, truth be told, I only bought it because it was so cheap and I hoped it could fill a few hours one boring evening after work. Oh, sweet Mass Effect, you didn't disappoint! There aren't many games that I genuinely wish I could remove from my memory, in order to replay again with a fresh set of eyes, but the exceptional story of Mass Effect, combined with the excellent character acting, life and death decisions that you'll face, and Shepherd's development and rise from traumatised soldier to first human Spectre, is a real work of genius. Despite this game being made in 2008 (I think), I only started playing it in March 2014. In total, I've spent around 43 blissfully happy hours running through the main story and side quests (excluding those pesky 'collect so many of this type of tag' quests). I know many games don't age well, but Mass Effect doesn't look old, nor dated, and if I didn't know the age of this game, I'd quite truthfully believe it was new and current.I'll close by saying that anyone not already familiar with Mass Effect should buy it immediately - well, if you like story driven games, of course. If not, just wait for a Steam Sale and buy it when it's virtually free!Now, enough singing the praises of Mass Effect - I was also fortunate enough to buy Mass Effect 2 in the same sale. I just hope it lives up to my lofty expectations and doesn't lose the excitement built from this true classic!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												So after all these years of hearing the hype I couldn't curb my curiosity any longer and finally bought Mass Effect and its sequel during the last christmas sales. As of now I've played about three quarters of Mass Effect and though I initially liked it I have to say I'm getting bored with it. Though that may sound negative I still give it a 3 out of 5 because it's a competent game but in my oppinion it doesn't deserve the praise it's getting.If you're familiar with Biowares previous products like Jade Empire and especially Knights Of The Old Republic (KOTOR)  you pretty much know what to expect from Mass Effect. Personally I think Mass Effect was probably meant to be another KOTOR installment, because its entire world could have been replaced with the one from KOTOR without much change, the Jedi order is now Spectre, the Jedi counsil is now The Counsil, the Force powers are now Biotic powers, the Twileks are now Asari, the Mandalorians are now Krogans and the list goes on. Maybe they couldn't secure the Star Wars license, not that it matters (unless you still care about Star Wars) because Bioware did a desent job in creating this new backdrop.Still I think this game shows why Bioware is becoming lazy as it's yet another save the universe story, which is way to similar to KOTOR. Like in Biowares earlier mentioned games, new partymembers join with no effort and are immediately willing to die for the cause. This is not only a missed opportunity for having better sidequests, it also makes their motives in joining meaningless. Mass Effect has some of the worst sidequests I've witnessed, the game has you looking for minerals with your APC by searching entire maps, to laughable moral decissions like wether a (completely bystanding) pregnant woman should have her baby inspected, which really made me question myself what I'm doing with my life by playing Mass Effect. For god's sake, Bioware please don't try to forcefeed me with morally responsible gameplay because you are terrible at it!As for the combat, the enemies are ridiculous bulletsponges which makes your weapons feel completely ineffective, I know this is in a lot of games but when I shoot something I expect it to hurt! As for me I was a bulletsponge too, so I didn't bother to make use of the coversystem much and I played on hard level. The shotgun and the assault rifle were the only usable weapons. I didn't see why I needed the pistol as drawing to a different weapon took as long as your gun to cool down and using the sniperrifle was like a drunk man playing darts. Another extremely annoying thing is that you have to have a high techlevel to be able to open all the containers, which in the end made me play only with Tali and Garrus as teammembers. I also thought that Mass Effect had rather poor graphics even for 2008, the characters have latexfaces, the leveldesign is rather bland and textures are very lowres, on the other hand I did like the music.So if you haven't played KOTOR or Jade Empire you might like Mass Effect more than me, if you have already played those you'll probably gonna need something to keep you awake while playing this game.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Hours are a lie (Were not recorded during offline for some reason). The main story took me around 12 or so hours to complete and I got to say that was one good half of a day. This is the first time I had ever played a mass effect game and with so much talk about how the 3rd ones ending wasn't good I didn't know what to expect, but what I did find was an extremely vast world full of spectacular different species and enviornments as well as a rich and well told narrative following the adventures of Commander Shepard and his crew. I would say the game is nearly perfect but its age has diffently shown. Gunplay seems fairly weak as a result of lack of feedback (imo) and the game is riddled with texture bugs, audio bugs and the occasional screen tear. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												What do you do when you're the only one who can save the galaxy? And the name of the main quest is called "A Race Against Time"?1. You take your time and explore the galaxy trying to find all the minerals, Turian insignias and Asari writings while not paying attention to what the bad guy is doing.2. You run out on inventory space 30 minutes into the game.3. You sell all of your unnecessary equipment and buy better equipment only to realise you're current equipment is better than what you just bought.4. You go to a planet that has a perma-blizzard and ride through it like a badass and end up killing everything in your way.5.  You flirt with your crew members (of opposite gender) and then bang them near the end6. You realise why Commander Shepard is one of the most badasss characters in gaming history.7. You get people to commit suicide by just speaking to them and they say thank you...8. Your very word can stop an argument.9. You kill the bad guy while looking badass...what did you expect..its a typical Bioware game..10. You repeat this whole process because you love the story so much!In all seriousness this game is amazing, even though I stopped playing it for a while because I didn't have much time on my hands, I've actually played this game 10 times on Xbox 360 and when I sat down to play it on PC I enjoyed it as much as I did when I played it for the first time on Xbox 360...the game was just a bit more difficult..maybe because I played it on Expert Difficulty. The game is beautiful, fun and well full of SPAAAAACE!! (See what I did there)...and sex..don't forget the sex...

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Mass Effect is one of the greatest RPGs in modern gaming. It definitely makes it in my top 10 games of all time. Even though its combat does seem stale and a bit boring the overall epicness and fun of the story definitely makes up for it. The writing definitely makes you feel like a grand space hero and an important figure. All choices do matter and you regret some of them due to the outcome. The character Customization does fall a little short with very little options to chose from. The game sometimes feels unbalanced and can sometimes be extremely difficult. There are some moments with bad dialogue like during combat with enemy and some NPCs. The overall experience is very grand and very fun but it does have some flaws that are a bit annoying. P.S dont even get me started on the elevator rides on the citadel. I give it a 8.2\10 An Amazing and must own game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I just got this for a couple of bucks, and after not playing it for several years, I got to say that this game has aged quite well in my opinion. For today's standards (regarding graphics and whatnot), it still holds up, and has some pretty good visuals. They do look a bit dated, of course, but for a game originally released in 2007, it looks great. Several people have complained about the Mako (driving) sections, and while the controls are a bit wonky, it still is a good idea, and it's not as bad as most people make it sound. And now,  let's talk about the heart of this game, and what makes it so special; the expanding, interesting, epic and completely immersive story filled with fully fleshed characters that you care about, amazing plot-twists, and an open ended narrative. This is what makes the ME series so special, along with it's bigger-than life space opera setting. Finally, I have to say that this game is a bargain. It offers at least 30 hours of gameplay, and if you explore every little corner and do every single side quests, those 30 hours could easily stretch to 50. Get this thing ASAP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Wow. What a fantastic experience this game was.I've heard so much about this game before actually getting myself to finally play it. Mainly because I'm not a fan of SCI-FI or shooter. Well I wasn't, before I started Mass Effect. This game is incredible. It will drag you in with it's fantastic gameplay, brilliantly written story with massive lore, amazing character development, beautiful music, beautiful landscapes, unique atmosphere, masterfully done voice acting and some of what are probably one of the most memorable characters in the game history. This is one of the rare games I actually finished. I have the tendency to play too many things at once to focus on a single game alone. This game, however, was an exception and getting it was probably one of the best decisions I've made in my life. I got it on sales for an € or so, but it is not only worth it's original price, but double that. I recommend this game to everyone everywhere that cherishes brilliant dialogues, deep character development, huge lore behind the main story, for people that don't want to just walk straight forward and shoot stuff, but for people that enjoy exploring the world they are in, for people that enjoy making decisions and think logically. Truly a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												A bad port of what was already the weakest game in the seriesThis game isn't good, simply put. Even when not compared to ME2 which I consider to be a perfect game, this is sub-par. The graphics have aged poorly, the characters are decently written but still underwhelming, the copy-pasting of levels and the shallow pool of enemy dialogue is likely to drive you insane, the menus and inventories are awful, and the game features little actual feedback for your choices and instead creates an illusion of depth that isn't there.And that's not even going into the quality of the PC port. No controller support, constant glitches both minor and serious, the game constantly changing it's own volume without player input at times setting the volume to max during an already loud cutscene and actually requiring that I remove my headphones, characters will switch back and forth between filtered and unfiltered voice lines so that the Elcor diplomat will sound like an Elcor at one line and a human on the next, save file corruption, abysmal optimization and screen tearing, dialogue skipping on it's own, and game breaking bugs that will trap you in loading and menu screens until you close the game.If you can look past all that, this game is still good. And I would consider it necessary to play to enjoy the next two games fully. Play it once and import your character into ME2 for the optimal experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2013
												The first part of one of the most immersive and fascinating video game series' of all time. The music alone deserves a playthrough, not to mention the amazing and complex storyline and the many interesting details that can be found throughout the insanely well-crafted universe. I will never forget Chora's Den or Flux (Shepard-dance, anyone?), the heart-wrenching decisions I had to make, the friends I have found (Anderson! Garrus! Wrex!), or the romances I've had (Ashley! Liara!), and despite the evident weaknesses the game has, when it comes to game mechanics for example, it is still one of my all-time favorites, surpassing even the following games, ME2 and ME3, in some areas. Making different decisions does not only change the course of the story, so that you discover new witty and interesting dialogs every time you play through the game (Shepard: "I'm p*ssed off. When I get p*ssed off, I shoot things.", discovered on my 3rd playthrough), they do also have an effect on the two successors. My suggestions is this: Get the game, make your OWN Shepard (not the standard one!) and just f*cking enjoy! Take your time, however: This game is not something for ADS kiddies who usually play CoD or Battlefield. It is like a good book, except for all the additional benefits the medium video game has to offer. A gem of a game for connoisseurs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I'm recamending this game because of all the Sci-Fi adventure games this one is at the top; it really captures the feeling of Star Trek, a feeling utterly missed by every Star Trek game. But with that said, this game is far from perfect, mostly because it is faced with some massive annoyances: -Unskippable and unpausable cut scenes -A terrible autosave system -Boss's that are just enemies with a massive health bar  -Broken Quick Save SystemThese may not sound like little problems, but lets look at what they all cause. OK lets say you die, not that rare, there are a lot of enemies that can 1 to 2 hit you if you can't see them, this means you are relying on the last save point, but since the environments are so big that means the last auto save could be 30mins ago. ALSO, if there are any cutscenes that occur your going to have to go through them again because unlike 99% of all other games that would autosave your progress after a cutscene, in this game thats not the case. BUT wait there is quick saving right? Wellllll, quick saving only works if there are no enemies, so if there is a string of enemies a long a 30 min trek you are♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck my friend. The game should keep track of 3 quick saves and allow you to quick save at any point that, that way i don't need to repeat the same 45 mins of my life over again like some lamer version of Groundhogs Day and if I quick save a death by accident I could use the previous quick save. Also, the last boss is a measure of your patients as he is health bar Mcgee, not hard, just repetative and boring.Overall Its a good game, I just wise it didn't make me feel like I was getting in the way of it's story all the time.

They managed to make a super awesome shooter RPG with 6 different classes and an adequately complex levelling system and inventory management. And for Mass Effect 2 they threw all of that out the window, removed the whole inventory thing completely and made the levelling system the simplest any RPG has ever had, which is why I hesitate to call Mass Effect 2 or 3 an RPG.This one also has the best story, and so it's pretty much better than Mass Effect 2 and 3 in every way, except for graphics. 10/10 best Mass Effect game to date, fingers crossed for Andromeda.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												For any gamer out there, Mass Effect is a must play.  This game is a third-person, role playing, story-driven shooter and it successfully accomplishes all it sets out to be.  The main storyline clocks in at around 13 hours but the game is packed with other missions and planets to explore on your own time.  Throughout the exploration and firefights, you will surely become attached to certain characters, so decisions you'll have to make later will put you in a cold sweat.  Shooting mechanics in this game are solid, but sometimes feel lacking.  As for the leveling system, not all the skill points you earn feel as if they've gone to any use since there is such a large array of skills and plenty of point slots necessary to fill so as to reach the next power.  All in all, this game is highly recommended to anyone looking for a fantastic single player game.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												I was struggled for a very long time if I should buy this game or not.I regret that I didn't buy it sooner.It is one of the Top 10 best games I have played. The gameplay might be a bit monotonus, but rewarding items, the story and your possible decisions make up for it.When I first played it I was AMAZED by how well every detail is described. Why the machines and weapons work and what they do. What every alien species backstory is and why they behave like they behave.It's a whole new universe to discover. I haven't seen any game before that cared so much about filling every logical hole and describing so much details, expanding the story to such great amounts. Awesome!Also, if you're a fan of astronomy, you'll love it so much more. Enjoy the most epic views of standing on a planets moon, being on a planet of a binary star system, or watch thousands of meteors raining down from the sky.As a fan of science, you might notice some physical details which aren't correct as they are. Like planets temperature described as going below the point of absolute zero (-273,18°C is not possible), our local sun shining yellow in space, or other little details. Nothing what would involve gameplay or bother you in some way.All in all, great game. I love it, I am a fan of the Mass Effect Universe now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Mass Effect is probably one of my most played games to date (just behind Mass Effect 2). Although I believe Mass Effect 2 is the superior of the two games in question (1 and 2), this is where the journey began - and should begin for you. I would (and do) highly recommend the Mass Effect Trilogy to anyone who finds themselves enthralled with single player experiences and Mass Effect is one of the best you can find.I am currently on my second playthough of the Mass Effect Trilogy and I'm sure when I'm finished I will jump straight back in to Mass Effect 1 again. Mass Effect follows what I like to call the "constants and variables" theory of storytelling. This means that the story has a few key sections that all players will experience, yet the road there can be different from person-to-person. Moreover, the types of decisions you make can also affect the outcome these "constant" events. The main decision elements come from your ability to either take a Paragon (good) or a Renegade (somewhat evil, more of a♥♥♥♥♥♥really) approach to decision making, earning points through doing so allows you to automatically open up more conversation options to enhance your experience.I personally feel that Mass Effect has pretty good character customisation - with not just how they look, but how you lay out your play style for the rest of the game. Being an infiltrator allows you to snip enemies from afar to deal a lot of damage. Whereas, you have a soldier who is a master of all weapons and usually likes to be in the thick of the action. The same can also be said of a Vanguard, they mix the world of Biotics (like superpowers) and guns together.The only downside to Mass Effect 1 is the glitches that can occur (and usually do for me), but a quick google of fixes usually resolves the issue. The hacking system is also only a minor gripe at what is one of my favourite games.In conclusion, the positives of Mass Effect extremely out weight the negatives. 9/10 from me (because it's not Mass Effect 2)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The first entry in the Mass Effect trilogy is both the start of a much larger story and a superb stand-alone experience. It created a rich sci-fi setting and infused it with deep RPG-style gameplay and great interactive dialogue; it was also BioWare's first foray into cover-based shooting, which would become a defining element its sequels.The most impressive feature of Mass Effect is the writing; characters and environments are all well-developed, and the story contains many powerful, unforgettable moments. Also impressive is the variety in the gameplay, which includes deep dialogue trees, complex shooting, and exploring the galaxy for resources and optional quests. There is an extensive amount of micromanagement required when equipping weapons, armor, and mods for each character; it can be cumbersome, but also adds a good deal of depth and replay value. Compared with its sequels, Mass Effect feels very rough around the edges. There are a number of bugs and glitches – some fun, others annoying – along with inconsistencies in difficulty and other inconveniences like long elevator rides. The lack of polish hurts the game, but never stops it from being fun. Problems and all, Mass Effect is a tremendously entertaining game that still has strong appeal for RPG fans and anyone who loves a great sci-fi story. It's also worth checking out for those who only played the sequels, provided they're willing to be patient with some of its less accessible features.(Rating: 8.5/10 “Excellent”)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												I don't have the Mass Effect triology on steam, just the first game, so I'm going to put my reviews of all three games here. As I play the games, I will add onto this review. I am also fairly confident that I am leaving all spoilers, or at least most, out.Mass Effect 1 Review:Storyline: Amazing. One of the best. Better than Half Life and SW:KOTOR (The best two I've ever played)The character building in this game is AMAZING. See, they kill one good guy in the first game, and at first, you're all sad and angry when they did it. You're raging with tears in your eyes. I say, wait a second. Hold up. You're getting these emotions because the developers did their job. The characters have emitted extreme amounts of personality, and those personalities you have become attatched to. This isn't a reason to get angry, it's a reason to appreciate the developer. There is a scene in this game where a good guy dies, and no matter how much of a cold, heartless, emotionless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you are, you will feel the emotions. You will cry a little bit. Others will cry alot. This just means that they did their job right. I mean, some of the guys in this game just show so much personality..      it's rare, but amazing. Graphics: Stale in certain aspects, but still amazing. Humans look realer than real. Aliens look..     just really, really real. When you talk to a character named Wrex, look at the lighting, the detail, everything. He looks..     just, amazing. It's like that for everyone. Screen effects are also good, as well as lighting effects.Mechanics: No such thing as headshots, but other than that, this is perfect. There is also a auto aim feature if you want to play the game with your eyes closed, or when drunk.Weapons: Annoying and worthless as♥♥♥♥♥♥in the early game, but they progressively get better. Overpowered as hell in the end of the game and in the second playthrough.Squad Ideas: Very useful. Little bit of ideas from Republic Commando, some from SW:KOTOR, and some from Ghost: Recon. Only the best. Freedom: It's the kind of thing where you think that the game has so much content because you're doing as much as you can and you're not hitting the boundaries, but little do you know that the boundaries are milimeters after what you're testingMMO Aspect: Still presentContent: Almost unlimited. This game took me 69 hours to compelte my first playthrough. I went a pure week straight of doing nothing with my life other than playing Mass Effect for 20 hours a day. Literally, only breaks I would take are sleeping and♥♥♥♥♥♥breaks. I can do that now that I'm off school for the summer.Comfortable for long gaming sessions, and I wouldn't have it any other way.The astronomy in this game is also a nice touch. See, for me, there's nothing more interesting than other planets, stars, solar systems, space, and things like that. You can explore so many planets, so many solar systems, stars, it's amazing. You kind of have to be obsessive with astronomy like I am to appreciate it, but I had a good 20 hours of heaven just exploring these planets and things like that. About a third of them you can land on and explore. All of them have stories and descriptions. It's just, amazing.Advice: 1. LISTEN to the dialogue. That's how the story is built. Study it like you were in college listening to a professor. 2. Do the mission on planet Virmire last. You're squad is permanently weakened for the rest of the game here.3. Talk to your companions between every mission you do, even if it seems they constantly have nothing new to say (which is rare)4. For god's sake, save frequently!5. Don't ♥♥♥♥ 2 ♥♥♥♥♥es at a time. That won't make them happy, and you'll get no ♥♥♥♥♥ at all. If you want to ♥♥♥♥ 2 ♥♥♥♥♥es, ♥♥♥♥ one in your first playthrough, and ♥♥♥♥ the second in the next playthrough.6. Save on to your savegame files. You can import your character into the next game, which includes your decsisions. If you save someone, they save you in ME2 or ME3. If you execute someone, they'll probably have a person in their life who will stop at nothing to cause you major inconveniences.7. MAX OUT YOUR CHARM ABILITY, and go paragon! Star Wars has light side and dark side. Paragron is the light side. Renegade is the dark side. Going Paragon is pretty much hitting the blue conversation option every time it appears. You can save all of your companions (but one) if you do! And the ones you save will come back to save you in the next game!Mass Effect 2 Review:Mass Effect 2 all depends on how you play it, what you get done, and when you do it. If you do it wrong, you will be so angry with this game ruining the story that you will never play a Mass Effect game ever again. Trust me. If you plan to play it, take my advice. There's an ending in this story where had I gotten it, I can tell you that I would have spend every last breathe of my life tracking down who ever the hell ruined the game and giving him a long, painful death. If you can get away from this terrible ending, however, the game is very, very impressive and very, very admirable. I already told you what I think of the game with the bad ending, now I'm going to tell you what I think of the good ending and the rest of the game.First Impression on Controls: "Wow, these controls are screwey! Spacebar is sprint? Shift is my ability overlay? What the ♥♥♥♥! I'm changing!"5 minutes later..Okay, still annoying.♥♥♥♥♥♥controles.2 hours later..Okay, not too bad.Now..♥♥♥♥ing amazing.Be sure just to change your controls to what you're used to, but make sure you keep Q and E as their defaults. Trust me on that. No matter how painful it is, you will adapt, and it will be worth it.First Impression on Story: "What the ♥♥♥♥? No! DUDE WHAT THE ACTUAL ♥♥♥♥! I'm uninstalling. ♥♥♥♥ the developers. ♥♥♥♥ ME. ♥♥♥♥ Bioware. ♥♥♥♥ YOU!"30 minutes later.."Joker? JOKER I LOVE YOU YOU ARE AMAZING I WANT TO HAVE MY KIDS WITH YOU!"2 hours later.."I don't appreciate the beginning, but I see why they did it."6 hours later.."Wow. Wow. Wow. Okay. Just, Wow. I love this game. I don't believe it, but I forgive them for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ beginning. In fact, I'm kind of glad it happened."Now"I understand why they did it, and I don't care. I've even gone back to watch it again and it couldn't seem to hit my 'care' button"Advice:1. Do all of your loyalty missions for your companions BEFORE doing the IFF mission. Pretty much talk to them and do them a few personal favors. No, I'm not telling you why. No, I'm not telling you what IFF is. I said I'd keep spoilers out, and I feel I have a very good job. 2. Upgrade you ship. 100%.  Trust me. 3. If you have to get a savegame editor to be able to afford the materials to do it, I understand, and will provide you with a download link to one. It will take hours of just pure scanning planets for materials in order to afford them all.http://social.bioware.com/project/4373/4. Save frequently.5. Max out your squad's and your own class ability. These abilities pretty much max out the damage and health of someone. After you're done with that, if you're a soldier, for yourself, max out the disrupter and the incidiary ammo. Very useful agains droids, and very useful against flesh. After maxed out, make them squad incidiary and squad disrupter ammo.Mass Effect 3 Review: Pending

Posted: August 15, 2014
												Where it all began! The first chapter in one of Bioware's greatest franchises... and then Mass Effect 3 :P+ Great tactical RPG/Shooter hybrid combat system+ Myriad of customization options for your Shepard and every companion you have+ Very well written plot that does a good job setting up events for the sequels+ Good graphics powered by Unreal Engine 3+ High quality character models and decent textures for weapons and armor+ A fair amount of sidequests and collectibles to find, both for codex entries and just for rewards+ Much of the game will hold your attention for extended periods of time, due to set pieces throughout and plot developments that you may or may not anticipate+ Great voice acting talent for all companions and most NPCs- Overly complex inventory system- After the first mission (Eden Prime), the game becomes slow for a period of time- Many class abilities ultimately become irrelevant and redundant as the game progressesAll in all, Mass Effect 1 is a very solid and remarkable sci-fi RPG that serves its purpose of introducing the ME franchise in spades.89/100. Highly Recommended

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The first entry in the Mass Effect trilogy is both the start of a much larger story and a superb stand-alone experience. It created a rich sci-fi setting and infused it with deep RPG-style gameplay and great interactive dialogue; it was also BioWare's first foray into cover-based shooting, which would become a defining element its sequels.The most impressive feature of Mass Effect is the writing; characters and environments are all well-developed, and the story contains many powerful, unforgettable moments. Also impressive is the variety in the gameplay, which includes deep dialogue trees, complex shooting, and exploring the galaxy for resources and optional quests. There is an extensive amount of micromanagement required when equipping weapons, armor, and mods for each character; it can be cumbersome, but also adds a good deal of depth and replay value. Compared with its sequels, Mass Effect feels very rough around the edges. There are a number of bugs and glitches – some fun, others annoying – along with inconsistencies in difficulty and other inconveniences like long elevator rides. The lack of polish hurts the game, but never stops it from being fun. Problems and all, Mass Effect is a tremendously entertaining game that still has strong appeal for RPG fans and anyone who loves a great sci-fi story. It's also worth checking out for those who only played the sequels, provided they're willing to be patient with some of its less accessible features.(Rating: 8.5/10 “Excellent”)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												In my opinion this game is the best of the Series, because it's the least streamlined one with the most choices and freedom of play and with the least amount of completely linear nerfhearding tunnelmaps. The combat in ME3 is better, but the cost is too high. Pro:+ Lots of different guns and armor with a ton of different mods. Lots of useless ones too. + Lots of dialogue and very few cutscenes. + Pretty funny dialogue choices at times, especially the Renegade options can be pretty funny and abusive. + Big square planet maps & the Mako. The only game in the ME series with a tactical choice. + Experience points for Kills. Time to go hunting for Thresher Maws & Geth! + Unlimited ammo, but with overheating and recoil. Nice diversity of guns and mechanics. + Import of previous 'veteran' characters.. Practically no level limit..  + Lots of skills. Cons:- The dialogue choices doesn't quite reflect what's being said. Quite often far from it. It's a gamble. How's that RPG?- Quite often different dialogue options leads to the same result or none at all. Just for show. - Once you are overloaded you can't sort through your entire inventory to scrap the least useful ones in favor of the last additions, which often happens to be a lot better than anything else you've got.. (Bleh, Of course). - No three-some!! Just like any other BioWare game it enforce ancient and unnatural monogamous relationships.

												Good game, not as good as its sequals in my opinion but it sets off the story nicely. It is very satisfying to be able to use the same character you have created through all three games and to have a story that continues in Mass Effect 2 and 3. This game has action, interesting enemies, weapons and NPC's as well as a very interesting, and sometimes hilarious, relationship build-up with a member of your team. A training instruction before the real action starts would have helped me from constantly dying early on. Something I appreciated to Mass Effect 2 were the "Combat Training" videos that guided you to understanding how to fight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Very good Sci-fi RPG.You choose a class and level your characters like any other RPG game, but the combat is a real-time 3rd person shooter. Building and strengthing your character is just as important as your ability to dodge enemy fire, use cover, and score headshots for critical damage. The game also has different difficulties settings to choose from in case you need to lower it. You also have 2 teammates with you at any given time.Aside from combat; you can literally spend hours at a time just going around exploring, talking to people, and reading codexes you come across (bits of information about certain guns or whatever). Some people love this stuff, others hate it, so its purely preference if you'll like it or not. The main highlight of this game though is the option to choose your own path/dialogue. You can pretty much apologize to someone, agree to disagree, or sometimes just straight up punch them in their face. Then the next time you meet this person down the road, IF you meet them again, they'll remember how the previous conversation went and it affects the feel of the game. It might even open or close off certain things. The overall core storyline of the game is the same though, you can't change that. It's also a trilogy. Certain decisions you make can span from game 1 game into the next if you transfer save files.It's a well-made game for its genre (and an even better trilogy). So if you're not into these type of games (Sci-fi / shooter / Action RPG / deep storytelling with alot of decisions and information/lore) then you simply won't like it.Cons: A few times playing this game I had to load an older save file due to some weird glitches happening. Maybe 3 times in 50+ hours of playing. (only lost a total of 10 minutes of playtime or so). Other than that the game ran fine for me.

												I highly recommend this game for anyone who is interested in a FPS game with a rich story.You can explore the milky way galaxy with many solar systems, all having their own planets. The main storyline is engaging and fun, and the side quests are meaningful and often change the dialogue you can exchange with other characters. The romantic subplots are also very interesting and allow insight into the background of your characters. The option to play as a Paragon or a Renegade based on the qualities of your actions is also a nice dynamic allowing moral feedback for your character. All in all, one of the best games I have ever played and definitely has a high replay value.

content:
Posted: January 5
												This one had the best gameplay in the series in my opinion. Probably going to get lynched for saying that but it's true. This is the only Mass Effect that is actually an RPG. They managed to make a super awesome shooter RPG with 6 different classes and an adequately complex levelling system and inventory management. And for Mass Effect 2 they threw all of that out the window, removed the whole inventory thing completely and made the levelling system the simplest any RPG has ever had, which is why I hesitate to call Mass Effect 2 or 3 an RPG.This one also has the best story, and so it's pretty much better than Mass Effect 2 and 3 in every way, except for graphics. 10/10 best Mass Effect game to date, fingers crossed for Andromeda.

												I picked this up during the X-mas sale and only recently installed it. I generally don't play shooters, but Mass Effect has a healthy dose of searching and exploring and story. I've always played "lurkers" in games, rather kill from the shadows. }:>I chose the Infiltrator class (I know, my friends are totally shocked) even though I read from several sources that the sniper rifle was a pain to master. It is a pain, but I can live with that. Took me more than a few occasions to unlearn that the spacebar does not make you jump... probable the only thing that bothers me so far. Because when I explore I like to jump and climb on things. I'm enjoying it very much so far at least I would hope so considering that I logged 6.6 hours on my first night of playing. :)So yeah, I'd recommend it.PS: sinewav put up a nice beginner's guide that explains the classes pretty well and what he considers their strengths and weaknesses, recommendations on how difficult newbs might find each class, on the crew you should pair up with them to fill in the holes. It might even open or close off certain things. The overall core storyline of the game is the same though, you can't change that. It's also a trilogy. Certain decisions you make can span from game 1 game into the next if you transfer save files.It's a well-made game for its genre (and an even better trilogy). So if you're not into these type of games (Sci-fi / shooter / Action RPG / deep storytelling with alot of decisions and information/lore) then you simply won't like it.Cons: A few times playing this game I had to load an older save file due to some weird glitches happening. Maybe 3 times in 50+ hours of playing. (only lost a total of 10 minutes of playtime or so). Other than that the game ran fine for me.

content:
Posted: February 14
												I picked this up during the X-mas sale and only recently installed it. I generally don't play shooters, but Mass Effect has a healthy dose of searching and exploring and story. I've always played "lurkers" in games, rather kill from the shadows. }:>I chose the Infiltrator class (I know, my friends are totally shocked) even though I read from several sources that the sniper rifle was a pain to master. It is a pain, but I can live with that. Took me more than a few occasions to unlearn that the spacebar does not make you jump... probable the only thing that bothers me so far. Because when I explore I like to jump and climb on things. I'm enjoying it very much so far at least I would hope so considering that I logged 6.6 hours on my first night of playing. :)So yeah, I'd recommend it.PS: sinewav put up a nice beginner's guide that explains the classes pretty well and what he considers their strengths and weaknesses, recommendations on how difficult newbs might find each class, on the crew you should pair up with them to fill in the holes. And I think he did a good job of it without filling it with spoilers. You can find it here: 


YouTube™ Video: Mass Effect - Ending Song 

			Views: 2,619,869		

			Jack Wall and Sam Hulick -M4 Part 2 (Faunts)		

EDIT:  Since I have a relatively new machine, ME wouldn't even launch on first attempt, a quick search will reveal 2 things that can solve this: Set the .exe to run in Admin mode and to download a legacy Nvidia driver. The first one worked for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												If you're looking to play this game then buckle up, kiddo, you're in for a ride.Experience the beginning of the epic journey with your custom or default Commander Shepard with a gender of your choice.Get sucked into a huge universe so full of lore, that three games wasn't enough to fit it all in, no, there's books (three worth mentioning and one worth forgetting) and comics and even a movie. AND there's another game coming next year, how great is that?Explore a vast galaxy with numerous planets to land on in a huge number of clusters.Freeze your lovely behind off on Noveria, jump the Mako over pits of Lava on Therum or stomp Geth with them (the Mako rocks, I don't care what anybody says), enjoy the scenery on Virmire (because that's the only thing you'll be enjoying there) and get lost on Ilos (every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time).Find loyal companions to fight by your side and befriend them. Maybe even smooch them if you feel that way. You can even smooch non-humans. Or not. Have it your way, really, this game is all about your choices and how they affect all the living beings in the galaxy.Make choices that affect everyone. Make choices that seem minute to you but grow monstrously in size and come back to bite you in your lovely behind later. Make choices that might kill people you know.Prepare for the biggest fight of your life.Be brave, be badass, be bad at dancing, be Commander Shepard.And after you're done? Well there's still two more games for you to question your choices, cry a lot (this is not optional) and start a new playthrough because you didn't need your heart intact anyway.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												If you are into the Mass Effect series, you should play through this game at least once.You play as commander Shepard, a military Alliance Officer on the spaceship Normandy. On a routine mission, you accidentaly activate an alien artifact, leading to a series of events that affect the galaxy as a whole. You pick up several squad mates along the way, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. The strongest reason to pick this one up is the superb story. It has some interesting twists and turns, which had me on the edge of my seat multiple times. this story really sets the tone for the second and third games. As this is a proper Bioware title, expect plenty of romance options and spot on dialogue. The story is definitely the best of the series. The second to me felt more like a big sidequest and let's not even talk about the third. Mass Effect really sets up the universe nicely and introduces you to all of the different alien races and worlds. Also, you can import your Mass Effect save file on the second game, allowing you to retain the universe as you left it and this leads to interesting conversations and unexpected meetings.It's not all good though. The graphics definitely look dated. Fortunately, there are some mods out there that somewhat fix this. The combat is definitely the worst in the series. Abilities have long, individual cooldowns, and most guns feel completely useless until you've specced heavily into their respective skills. Also, the different classes aren't balanced well. Some are definitely a lot stronger than others, resulting in multiple viable playstyles and team setups. The weaker classes are simply not as fun to play. Also, on higher difficulties most enemies get insane damage resistance, without really getting stronger or smarter. This draws the game out, without adding a significant challenge. Mass Effect 2 did this much better. The planet exploration sections are pretty bad, but fortunately they are mostly skippable.In summary, get this game if you really like sci-fi or you've already played the second and third Mass Effect games and love the universe. It's definitely not a bad pickup for anyone else, but for the money there are plenty of better options out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												A truly fantastic and great game. Though I'm incredibly late to the party, I'm glad I finally decided to play through and beat this game. For the most part, it's a 3rd person shooter, but it's not typical. At the same time, the gameplay isn't exactly groundbreaking. There's elements of customization, minimal squad control that makes this game stand out from other 3rd person shooters, and space navigation that isn't too hands on. What really grabbed my attention about this game was its immersiveness and the setting that is gradually revealed to you. For the most part, the story isn't also particularly original *SPOILER WARNING* it involves you chasing after a rogue alien who's attempting to bring the downfall of all known civilizations in this game's galaxy. Though that isn't quite original, the way the story is revealed to you is quite interesting. Through journal entries, conversations, and general observations, you as a player begin to learn about the setting of this game. Though it's not essential to the game, you can exhaust character conversations in order to be better informed of what's going on outside of the game's storyline. Overall, I rate this game a 4/5 and I highly recommend it if you're into action RPGs and enjoy science fiction as much as I do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I admit that, even though I had heard so many good things about the ME series, I didn't actually try out the game until now. And even though it's not exactly state of the art anymore... it still managed to get me hooked quickly. Yes, it's a few years old, yes, the graphics won't do well if compared to more recent games. But OMG, talk about an immersive game. There are quite a few similarities to KOTOR 1 and 2... its obvious it's the same developer. So if you enjoyed the incredible stories in the KOTOR-games, give this a try. KOTOR of course also was fun because it was set in the SW-universe, and in a very interesting era of that franchise, the old republic. Jedis, the Force, the Dark side etc.So I wasn't sure I'd warm up to a very different universe and franchise. And even though I haven't progressed very far yet, I already do care a lot about the story and the characters. Amazing. The story IS captivating, and so is the combat. It's not the turn-based lightsaber/force-combat of KOTOR, of course - instead, its a tactical shooter, not turn-based. And it's FUN even though I'm usually not at all into that genre at all. I haven't even used my squad that much, still warming up to controlling and using my companions but even without that deeper element of the game, I enjoy the action-part of the game a lot. Taking cover, using tactics, choosing your wep, trying to find a good tactic or going for the dangerous method... FUN. And again, I usually am not a fan of shooters. The story is totally captivating and interesting. I am not sure whether the balance will work for everyone (sometimes, there is a lot of running around, talking to people etc, before it goes back to action), but for me it works. And the speech Capt. Anderson gives to his crew rather early on in the game actually gave me goosebumps, I admit it. Heroic moment ftw. The writing rocks, and so do the characters.Now, keep in mind this game is a bit older. Apart from the graphics which isn't state of the art, there are some issues with the combat. Sometimes, you might be taking cover but can't fire for some reason. You can see the enemy, have a clear line of sight, yet can't shoot until you move a bit more. There are some issues with the Mako too...driving it can be fun, but I had some situations where it bounced like a rubber ball and fell off a cliff. Targeting with it has some issues too...clear line of sight at a drone, shoot, not hitting at all (keep in mind that you have to keep some distance in between the vehicle and enemies when using the Mako)The game, like KOTOR shows you a very clear path to your objectives. So you won't run around forever to find a special room... the path is dictated to you rather clearly. This might bother some, I was ok with it. The Citadel is a bit confusing sometimes, but that's ok. I am amazed by how quickly the game captivated me, and I'm not even far into it yet! I can perfectly understand just why this game is so popular and revered. DOn't let the age scare you away (same with Kotor, and this game looks much better). Amazing.Edit: about 10 hrs in... the story gets even more interesting, and the game really makes you think about dialogue choices and decisions you make. It's not always black and white for sure, and I am planning on using my save games to continue through ME2 and 3, so I hope the choices are ok. If not, I'll start over =)EDIT: OK, finished it. I didn't do a lot of the side-quests, focussed mainly on the storyline. I am rather certain I will at some point go back, start over, try some different choices and do the side-quests too. Biggest complaint? It's TOO SHORT!!! (15.7 hours is what the Steam-counter says) However, it's thoroughly enjoyable. The storyline is totally fascinating, and often reminded me of the old Babylon 5-show regarding scope, mystery and background. Great writing, some fascinating twists, several fistpump-moments for the player.No wonder this game is so popular and beloved. On to ME2 now!!

												Mass Effect is an space adventure RPG like no other, one that will stand the test of time long after people forget about the ME 3 endings. While it is a great game it does suffer its flaws, such as the mako driving segments (which I personally like but I do understand and see why some wouldn't like it), the container minigames, and some of the side missions which can become tedious. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												In my opinion this game is the best of the Series, because it's the least streamlined one with the most choices and freedom of play and with the least amount of completely linear nerfhearding tunnelmaps. The combat in ME3 is better, but the cost is too high. Pro:+ Lots of different guns and armor with a ton of different mods. Lots of useless ones too. + Lots of dialogue and very few cutscenes. + Pretty funny dialogue choices at times, especially the Renegade options can be pretty funny and abusive. + Big square planet maps & the Mako. The only game in the ME series with a tactical choice. + Experience points for Kills. Time to go hunting for Thresher Maws & Geth! + Unlimited ammo, but with overheating and recoil. Nice diversity of guns and mechanics. + Import of previous 'veteran' characters.. Practically no level limit..  + Lots of skills. Cons:- The dialogue choices doesn't quite reflect what's being said. Quite often far from it. It's a gamble. How's that RPG?- Quite often different dialogue options leads to the same result or none at all. Just for show. - Once you are overloaded you can't sort through your entire inventory to scrap the least useful ones in favor of the last additions, which often happens to be a lot better than anything else you've got.. (Bleh, Of course). - No three-some!! Just like any other BioWare game it enforce ancient and unnatural monogamous relationships.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												What can I say about this game that already hasn't been said?I'll try and do this game justice with what I'm about to write.The story is brilliant and sets up the rest of the following games very well. Your choices matter and will affect the end result further down the line.Character development is strong. With Garrus being my favourite team member. Seriously, that Turian is awesome. Male Shepard and Garrus are the best bromance I've ever seen in a game.The RPG elements are in depth and gives you the opportunity to mould your character in any way you want.The combat is slightly lacklustre, but it can be forgiven and doesn't detract from the core game.One main negative that a lot of people didn't like was the Mako. Sure it was ungainly and could almost climb near vertical cliffs. But I rather enjoyed the exploration it opened up for you.You could travel to a planet, land on it and search locations noted on your map. Most of these locations didn't add anything to the main story line, but for me it brought me into the world more, it added lore and detail to the world.Mass Effect is starting to look slightly outdated these days, though that is a given considering that it's over 8 years old from its first release date.Buy this game, just for the fact that it'll suck you in and prepare you for the awesome ride that is Mass Effect 2 and most of 3. (I won't go into the details of 3 here, but I'm sure most people know of what I'm on about).
