number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A really good action/RPG game in every aspect. The story, voice acting, graphics, sound, music and gameplay are all good.The game seems like a fusion of Dragon Age, KOToR and Neverwinter Nights all wrapped up together in a wonderful package. If you liked any of those games, you will undoubtedly like this!You follow the path of Shepard (male or female depending on your preference) in a desperate attempt to save the galaxy from the ominous Reapers. Along the way you recruit companions, fall in love and make tough decisions. It also allows for a little exploration in form of the many sidequests. You get to select from a multitude of different classes and level-up and outfit the characters however you want. It also features a squad ordering system (although basic) to position your squad tactically. The combat is in the form of an over-the-shoulder third person, cover-based shooter. It works well here when combined with your squads various strengths and weaknesses.All-in-all, a very good game that I would recommend to everyone interested in the format.Jimbo Rating: 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2012
												Mass Effect is a game that is synonymous with quality. A role playing game set in a future of interstellar space travel, Mass Effect makes effective use of player choices and a lawful/chaotic alignment system all balanced with a class-based third person shooter combat system.The storytelling in the game is top notch  with memorable characters and many instances where player choice has a huge effect on the story's outcome. Many of these choice are also carried over into the sequel Mass Effect 2 as well as Mass Effect 3. It's rare that a game is conceived as a trilogy and even rarer when it turns out to be a masterpiece. If you've not played this game yet, you owe it to yourself to do so!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												As someone who's more of a FPS player, I occasionaly like playing RPG's because of the immersive experience they deliver. I only played Fallout 3 and New Vegas aside from Mass Effect so I don't have much experience in these type of games but here goes. The number one reason I kept playing through Mass Effect was the story. The game really let's you control how the story develops while being very interesting at the same time. It was very hard to get in to (haha..) and can be overwhelming for someone who has never played an RPG before, but when you get the hang of the skills, guns and inventory it will be pretty fun. Although I have to say I don't like the combat apart from the usable skills. Yes, you have a plethora of options for your guns, but the guns themselves stay the same through out the game: pistol, shottie, rifle and sniper + grenades. Maybe because I liked the skills more I didn't like the gunplay that much. If you like modding your gun (attachments+ammo type) you probably would like this game but I liked the Fallout 3 weapon system more. The story blows you away and that's what counted the most for me. I liked doing side missions a lot more than combat, but that's me. TL;DR: Want a great story +♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of upgrade options + items (although they're pretty much the same items with better stats)? Buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Totally needed to re-write this review.Mass Effect, the first installment in what was to become Bioware's crown jewel and redefine the gaming communities understanding of dynamic decision making. Personally ME1 is my least favorite of the series but without a doubt it is still a wonderful experience that left me with fond memories and stuck with me throughout my gaming life. I am going to write this review as if describing it's pros and cons to somebody who has never heard of or played Mass Effect, so bear with me:The first part of what makes Mass Effect so perfectly immersive to the player is that they all but become Commander Shepard himself/herself, choosing their name, gender, appearance, history, combat style and how they react to their environment, in this the game has not only a very high immersion factor but an even higher replay factor as well, playing the game again and making different choices only to see how the world and it's characters react and how it will impact the story in the future sequels thanks to a very well-versed save transfer system.The gameplay is a third-person perspective utilizing a cover system for combat, and while this cover system is merely a pioneer for the much tightened cover mechanics in Mass Effect 2+3 it was still rather unique at the time and generally unexpected for an RPG title. By pressing "space" (I don't remember what the default key is, so I'm just assuming it's space) the player can take cover in the environment to reduce incoming fire. I found it to be a unique aspect at the time and I was more than a bit disappointed that it wasn't utilized further, but as I said ME1's cover system was a "beta" for lack of a better word and paved the way for the perfected combat systems in the sequels.Mass Effect's story is compelling, made even more so by the fact that you yourself are the famous Commander Shepard and it is up to YOU, not some pre-determined protagonist, but YOU to proceed through the invasive forces of rogue synthetic drones to chase down a defected Spectre and put a cork in the bunghole of his plans all the while accompanied by a cast of lovable, memorable and very well-rounded allies.Some aspects of gameplay however were not all that good and I felt were a blemish on what could have been an otherwise perfect game. And this flaw has a name, the Mako. The Mako is your supposedly "trusty" all-terrain vehicle that you utilize in every single mission to reach your objective before you and your chosen squadmates proceed on foot. To quit dancing around the issue: the Mako is a clumsy and thorough mess. It controls like an old shoe and it has a horrible habit of overreacting to the terrain, spiraling out of control and more often than it should flies into environmental hazards. For this reason I was ever so thankful that vehicle sequences have never been looked into again for the Mass Effect series.A secondary flaw was inventory management: Scarcely a single RPG game can exist without armor and weapons that you pick up in your travels, and of course Mass Effect has this function as well. But managing the inventory and all your loot feels like an afterthought on the developers end, with no filters to sort your items through it ends up being a tedious waste of time to decide what to keep, what to equip on who and what to convert to omni-gel (which is some magical lotion you rub on electronic locks to open doors and containers to find even MORE crap). Without the nightmarish inventory management and the over-glorified brick known as the Mako I would say that Mass Effect is a near-perfect game despite it's smaller flaws.So in conclusion: Mass Effect, while personally I feel being the least enjoyable of the trilogy, is a brilliant game put together by ingenious writers and programmers, and remains to this day the opening chapter of one of the most industry-changing and cultrally influential series' on todays market. If you haven't played Mass Effect yet I sincerely recommend giving it a go, and I can personally guarantee that you will not leave disappointed.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Mass Effect is quite simply an awesome game. It holds up well over time because of its story, though for a circa 2006-2007 title it still looks all right. There is quite a bit of detail, and the character models are distinctive if stiff by next-gen standards. But the story. As Commander Shepherd (there's a metaphor for you), you suspect an elite inter-galactic covert operative named Saren has gone rogue and is in league with - something - in some kind of nefrarious activity against the galaxy. Signs of this activity are indicated by the growing presence of the militaristic Geth civilization, an AI-driven robotic organization (more will be discovered about them as the game progresses). Shepherd is tasked with investigating Saren. Along the way, you'll uncover secret military bases, testing labs, strange alien creatures (not all of them hostile!) corrupted intergalactic politicians, and allies of the most unexpected sort. The game starts slowly. If you are hoping to get some shooting action right away, you do (The Prologue - Eden Prime). But once the Prologue is finished, the action devolves into a snooze-fest of non-combat missions on the Citadel. You'll want to do most if not all of them, as they are an easy way to level-up early in the game, but could leave some who are hoping for more action disappointed. If you can make it past the Citadel missions, you'll get your own ship and commence on the real adventures. There is the scripted main story, which involves visiting three or four systems (some only appear later in the game). There are what I'll call the Character side missions: if you talk to the crew on your ship, they'll share parts of their past with you, some of which will provide the option for additional missions. And there is the option to simply explore the galaxy. There are a large number of star 'clusters', each with multiple planetary 'systems' that hide many different artifacts and resources; the discovery of either gives you money or points toward leveling up or both. In each system there is at least one planet that can be landed on and explored using the armored Mako Rover. The pattern is quite similar for each landing: land, explore, fight (usually), then leave. Fortunately the terrain and environments vary between planets varies quite a bit, even if the older graphics don't allow much terrain detail. There are ice planets, desert planets, lush earth-like planets. Even thoug hyou are wearing an environmental bio-suit, not every planet is safe to explore on foot. There are some planets that are level 1 or level 2 hazards: stay out of the Mako too long, and you'll risk dying as hazard intensifies. Picking your squad is actually one of the tougher challenges of the game. For each mission - combat or exploration - you are allowed to bring two crew members with you to make up your squad. At its peak, you will have six crew members to choose from, each with a different skill set. Who you need depends on your mission. For planetary exploration, you'll want to take someone good in Electronics and Hacking to opening any encrypted containers you might find is easy, as well as someone good in combat in case you run into any trouble. Facing alien life-forms? Taking along one of the biotics experts along might be a good idea. They are not as good in a firefight as somebody with a better combat rating, so evaluate your risks carefully.While there are a wide variety of weapons available, they will all look different but every genre feels the same as you fire  -i.e. all assault rifles fire the same, sniper rifles fire the same, etc. The difference is in the amount of damage they cause, how large the recoil is, how long it takes for the weapon to over-heat. The weapon specification system is actually quite deep, with the ability to option and upgrade weapons with a variety of in-game add-ons that enhance some of the weapon's abilities for a trade-off (choose tungsten rounds for high damage, for instance, but the weapon will overheat sooner).Combat is quite simple, being of the point-and-shoot variety, with (on PC) right-clicking to aim. There is a 'snap to cover' that involves no hotkeys. Simply move toward cover, and your character will snap into cover. Right-clicking from cover allows you to aim and shoot from cover. Most of the time this works well - not brilliant, but well. There are the inevitable times that you will be running to avoid getting hit with toxic puke or something similar and you will snap to cover when you really don't want to - and you will die in the process. Save often.In the process of getting to know your crew, there will be options in conversation for meaningful exploration of feelings and events happening around you in the game. In two cases (perhaps more) there is an option to 'romance' the other character. Any kind of result here is only obtained after painstaking going through a large number of coversations and giving 'correct' answers to questions and issues. So if you're hoping for some quick R-rated video-game 'action', look elsewhere. Who you choose is entirely up to you.Which leads to one of the most important elements of Mass Effect's conversation game-play, and the key to its high replay value: choice. There are about a dozen places in the game where you are required to make a choice that will impact how the game progresses. While the core ending involving the fate of the galaxy may remain the same, how you get there has many circuitous routes. Who do you save? Who do you spare? Who do you kill? Do you engage in conflict, or try to talk your way out? Choice and consequence is felt through-out the game, and ever-present in the final third of the game - even after the final fight / battle is over, there is yet another choice to be made. Put all of this together effectively, which Mass Effect does, and you have an amazing Role Playing Game that will take you on an immersive cinematic ride that many games have trouble simulating, let alone achieveing at this level. Mass Effect is a Massive Achievement for RPG's that continues to hold its place in the RPG Hall of Fame, despite its age. Postscript on bugs: There have been reports of a variety of bugs with the PC port of this game. My game would crash upon loading save files; deleting the Shader Cache in the MassEffectConfig application fixed that (had to do it every time I loaded the game, but it was worth it). I also had the famous black-pixelated-block player textures on certain missions that only seems to afflict users with AMD processors. Fortunately there is an easy workaround. If you are having a problem with this game, search the internet. Chances are, you are not alone!

content:
Posted: April 3
												Of all the Mass Effect games, this is only one which can be considered a true RPG with all the standard RPG fare intact.While the other entries in the series do a good job of personifying the Good (ME2), the Bad (ME3) and the Ugly (Andromeda), the original Mass Effect is the most distinct of the series - focusing less on the combat and more on traditional RPG mechanics and exploration of the galaxy.Graphically the game still looks good, albeit for a game which came out in 2007, although the combat feels dated unless you are of the Biotic God persuasion - although it does have elements which were sad losses from subsequent games in the form of greater squadmate controls and using lots of powers.Most importantly for a Mass Effect game, the writing of Mass Effect 1 is in another plane of existance compared to the later offerings, although Mass Effect 2 is still well written, and the depth of world building and genuine diversity (OF PERSONALITY) and memorability of the squadmates is excellent.If you want a sci-fi RPG that's well written, with a universe that you can, and will, get sucked into and fall in love with then Mass Effect is for you. However, this is debatably the high point for the franchise and rather than loving you tenderly and settling down happily ever after, the series will sour later on and leave you with a nasty taste in the mouth if you follow it through to the conclusion.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												(Keep in mind that I have over 100 hours on Origin and another 100 hours on Xbox, with a total of 9 full playthroughs across all three games with plenty more playthroughs on the other games.)I have tons of games in my library and love most of them, I've been holding off reviewing a game until I really felt I understood every aspect of the game and done all there is to do. Mass Effect is my absolute favorite series and will be until my death, it is an amazing game and has a beautifully crafted storyline. In this review I will go into detail on most aspects of the game and will explain both the good parts of the game as well as the shortcomings of it. I will keep this review as spoiler free as possible as well.Storyline:Right from the beginning of the game, even in the character creation, you feel like you are really in this universe. It really immerses you into the world and lore of the game. As you play through the game the storyline may seem to slow a bit as you’re doing your side quests and exploration but it will always feel like you’re doing something to help advance personal storylines of people that will play some role in Shepard’s mission. As you play through the other games in this series these storylines arc out more and more and intertwine in ways that you wouldn’t imagine. It is truly the single best part of the game and completely makes the game.Gameplay:The gameplay can be sort of clunky at times, especially during fights. The cover mechanic is a nice feature and is prevalent in all three games but can be glitch and you can end up doing something that’ll get you killed on accident. Perhaps the single worst part of this game is the driving and exploring in the M35 Mako which is the car you’ll find yourself in very frequently. It is the only thing that makes me dread another playthrough. The control scheme for it is very clunky and takes a LOT of practice to eventually get down. Other than that, the questing and interaction with NPC’s feels very natural and seamless. Everything that happens is there for a reason and nothing really feels out of place.Graphics:For a late 2007 game the graphics are pretty much on par and there isn’t too much to praise or criticize. Personally I don’t pay much attention to graphics and care a lot more about storyline and gameplay. Even though the textures and graphics aren’t that good the lore and storyline more than make up for the lack of amazing graphics.Lore:The lore of this game is completely amazing and in-depth. There is so much to the lore in this game that even I, someone who has read three of the four books and read the codex multiple times, still doesn’t know everything there is to know. Everything that has happened in the game has some amount of information behind it. I could go on for hours about all the technology and alien races in the game but I intend to keep this review somewhat short. I honestly can’t explain everything there is, the only way to truly experience is to play it for yourself.Rating: 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												My hour count may be low on steam, but on 360 I've played 7 full playthroughs with and all achievements unlockedThis game is a modern classic. It was 7th gen's KotOR.Remarkeable voice acting, atmosphere and story.The universe is on par with stories like Star Trek and even Star Wars with clear inspiration from those universes. This is easily one of the best, if not THE best scifi RPG out there. Its a great series, if you exclude ME3.I'll sum up what makes this masterpiece great in a simple list fornPROS:-Great voice acting-Great characters and villains-Although the Reapers are somwhat generic "ancient evils" they're still very interesting-The fully voiced protagonist with two genders shows how much work they put into the dialogue and making it as emersive as possible.-leads into a great trilogy (excluding the second half of ME3)-all races are interesting with lore behind them-different planets and have their own culture and feel. Lower-Citadel is a robust cyberpunk-like underworld where anything goes while Noveria feels like the Hoth we never got to explore (until SWTOR came along)-the atmosphere throughout the game is strong. You really do feel like the captain of a spaceship, exploring the universe and learning new thingsCONS:-meh gameplay. Significantly improved in ME2-graphical glitches present in this version and vary between person to person (judging by community posts)-Kaiden is almost as bad as Alistair-A lot of your choices don't really matter. The game gives you the illusion of choice. It make impact ME2 somewhat, but the choices you make in ME1 and 2 make no difference whatsoever in 3-Male Shepherd in this game has a very wooden voice actor. Femshep does a much better job. Mark Meer improves his acting in ME2-Shepherd overall isn't a very interesting character after the 10 minute intro. You can choose his/her origin story which is great but it's only loosely referenced in the game and it doesn't make as much an impact as your origin does in Dragon Age: Origins (another great RPG by BioWare)-most of the time, you're only fighting Geth which is a shame since the galaxy is booming with much more life. It gets stale seeing the same model fall over and over when you could be fighting a limitless amount of different species. Some planets let you fight rachni and krogan but these moments are few and far between. It feels like wasted potential. Again, ME2 improves on this.To sum it all up, it's a flawed masterpiece. The atmosphere, story, and characters are fantastic but the ho-hum gameplay and wooden protagonist leave a lot to be desired. ME2 is an overall better game but this game remains my favorite in the series because it gives you a sense of curiosity and wonder that only few games manage to give me.8.5/10

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												The beginning of an epic saga! If you're not a fan already, then prepare to become one. In this well balanced RPG game, you call the shots as you lead a crack team of warriors on a mission to save the galaxy. The story is both engaging and intense, keeping you on the edge of your seat the whole way. Think carefully before making any decisions, as they can and will come back to haunt you in ME2 and 3. And prepare to get attached to your companions, as you may well lose them if you don't take care! While the gameplay itself can be buggy at times, it is incredibly intuitive given it was made in '07, though nowhere near as smooth as Crysis. For $20 you are getting something worth far more! So go ahead and download it! Yes I mean you, go ahead and click the download button! I can guarantee you won't regret it! And while you're at it, you might as well get Mass Effect 2, cuz you WILL be buying it after you get hooked on ME1. So save yourself the trouble and do it now. xD

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Perhaps the pinnacle of my experiences in the sci-fi genre. Something about the universe entraps me, making the world feel just believable enough while posing advances in science and sociology to retain the brilliance of science fiction. It gives a chance to make the character your own, with options that make you observe what you want to say, instead of having an idea of what will be 'good guy' or 'badass'. The universe offers a lot of reward for exploring and enterprise, making the game far longer than the set story.There are shortcomings obviously. The combat has slight hard-spots but its largely cooperative. Sometimes its worth saving before dialogue just to make sure you don't pick an option that you later find 'misleading'. Lastly, new OS's don't always get along with the game. I had to run Windows Software Troubleshoot to make it work, and afterwards the steam overlay stopped working.All in all, I encourage anyone who enjoys a game for its story and its gameplay, to fully immerse themselves in this series.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
rating: worth buying at full pricescore: 7.5/10 - goodsimilar games: Deus Ex Human Revolution, Dragon Age Origins, Spec Ops The Linetags: RPG, character development, story-driven, relationships, dull gameplayI finally got the motivation to play Mass Effect. After so many years of praise for this franchise I just said to myself that I HAVE to at least play it for a fair amount of time. I tried playing this game some years ago but the extremely dull gameplay immediately turned me off and male Shephard isn't really interesting as a character. This playthrough I started as female Shephard (suggested by many people) and that really made the game more interesting, but before I talk about the good things I want to talk about the dull gameplay.I keep saying the word dull because that's the most fair way to describe it I think, because its not really "bad", but you have no decisions to do as a player, you don't have to use your brain, you just keep shooting. That does not mean that it cant be fun though, but for me it wasn't. Sometimes it was really annoying, sometimes it had its moments, sometimes is was just consuming my time. The game would really benefit if they would reduce the combat and focus on characters instead, but I guess you have to please the mass market. The problems with the combat are the following: Enemies are bullet sponges, sound design is bad, AI is terrible, you have no interesting abilities, only your squad has, and weapons are unsatisfying to use due to ugly recoil and bad hit feedback. Its not terrible, considering the age of the game, but it really drags the game down.Another bad thing are the side-missions which are nothing but filler, completely meaningless and a waste of time. Most of them are the same recycled levels with other objectives, but even the objectives themselves are just go from A to B, kill everything on your way and press the action button at the end. There were some side-missions where you interact with characters, but those are very rare and those interactions only go for a very short duration. I recommend skipping every side-mission, except the ones you do for your crew-members (not all of them have missions for you).The main missions were really fun though, you get to an area which could be a planet, a station, something which works as a hub area. There you meet characters and things happen and you get like mini side-missions from some people which are okay since they don't take much time and the character interaction is what makes this game fun.What I like about the main missions is that you stay at one big hub area for a long time and have to do different objectives to achieve something and get to different places. That reminded me a lot of Deus Ex, and it works almost as good as in Deus Ex. Exploring these places and meeting characters from different races is interesting and fun. Only thing which breaks this a little bit are the extremely annoying elevators, which probably are just there to cover loading screens. The thing is if they would just put a loading screen there it would probably load in seconds, cause today we have better PCs, but this game was mainly developed for consoles, so they didn't think about that. Still there are some PC specific things, for example you have extra keys assigned to each weapon and keys assigned to things like inventory and journal.The graphics are very dated, but character models still look fine, and overall the game still looks good thanks to very creative weapon and alien design. Animations are sometimes really bad, in most cutscenes the character are just standing in front of each other and moving their lips a little, but that's fine, because it still works. To the end of the game you can see that they put much more effort to the presentation and cutscenes and the story also gets really tense later, but expect a slow start and don't kill your motivation by doing filler side-missions. Also after every main missions you should talk to every squad member, you get interesting and fun dialouges and build relationships.I think this is a good game, but a little bit overhyped. People praise it for its story, for good reason, but forget the gameplay, or they just don't care about it, I do however. That's why I can't give it a very good score, but a 7.5 is still good in my book and definitely worth playing if you can handle dull gameplay.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												A long long time ago in a galaxy far away...It was 2007, and Bioware launched their flagship title to the franchise we now know as Mass Effect.Was it worthy of praise and sequels? Does it hold up today?Yes, and yes.First of all, the universe is immense, with detailed lore written and performed via audio journals.(The games also spawned novelizations, merchandise, and a script for a movie has been in development since 2010)The game was among the first exploring morality, choice, and consequences can lead you down different paths.Aaaand here's where I lose some of you because of my opinion: I like the Mass Effect universe more than Star Wars universe, in fact, I am not much of a fan at all of Star Wars, not even the original trilogy. There, I said it.Did Star Wars inspire Mass Effect?Duh.I also like Doctor Who, Farscape, and other sci-fi worlds, and just take into consideration that a review is just an opinion.Ok anyone still with me?Why is Ashley Williams armor pink and white? It makes not one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bit of sense. She's a marine, not a sex robot. Sure, you can buy Ashley some upgraded armor and retire the pink-and-white "whywouldanyonewearthisinabattlefieldwhiteisimpossibletokeepcleannottomentionitsjustplainsexistatthispoint"peice of armor to rest....BUT WHY??!?!?!So apart from a few minor gripes, the game still crafts its story well and creates interesting choices for Shepard to face (even though "Renegade" Shepard is kind of a psychotic♥♥♥♥♥♥for no reason)Final Verdict:7.5/10 - Definitely worth putting in your collection, with ME2. Pity we'll never get ME3, but just go watch it on Youtube because ♥♥♥♥ EA.And if any of you make a sci-fi space epic, don't put the girls in "powderpuff" fashion armor.10/10 girls prefer not being shot thanks to some sexist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the armory.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												9.8/10 so close to a 10...This is a defining moment in gaming history, and it deserves to be. As a third person shooter alone it's pretty good, but when you combine the RPG elements it becomes truly one of the best games I've ever played. Of course, that's just the start, throw in the epic storyline which really does change as you make decisions, the people you'll meet and places you'll see, and it becomes a genuinely unmissable series. Shape your character into either the world's most badassful, ruthless killing machine, or the by-the-book man of justice with just 3 solar cycles until retirement. Then import that character into ME2, or replay as a whole new shep.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Recommended but i couldn't like it because only one but also important part of a game.Honestly everything is good. Story, dialogues, main and side quests, RPG elements... except combat system.Combat system is nearly horrible, cover shooting mostly doesn't work. For example you're in cover, leaning to a wall... an enemy just came to your near, you can look but you can't both shoot or aim to him. Crosshair is deceptive, shooting feeling is bad. In the end, fighting with enemies isn't flexible and in the end your main character dies because of combat mechanics. I got it, the game mostly based on role-playing but shooter/combat part of the game really sucks.Also if you stuck at a point which has a cutscene, you can't skip that cutscene and it ends up watching the cutscene over and over again.I really liked the game, so far i really enjoyed Citadel mission, speaking with NPCs and exploring the place were awesome. But... that's all. In that condition, i'd like to see a tactical strategic combat system instead of a mediocre 3rd person action.Also cloud support (for save game files), Steam overlay (a.k.a. in-game) features AREN'T available.So, if you're like me who intented to start Mass Effect series just now, please consider to play it somewhere else before buy...

content:
Posted: January 15
												True masterpiece , 9.6/10.     (100+ hours of game time but not on steam)     This game man... When Mass Effect 1 first came out I was really young and at that time I didn't really liked Star Wars and I thought they are the same thing (kinda). I was a bit prejudiced about it. One of my friends came to me and said "Hey there is a game called Mass Effect it rocks". I watched my friend playing it , I didn't really liked it. After some time I realized that many of my friends are playing it. I was like hey let's try it and bought the game. That might be the best decision of my entire life.       Many people doesn't like the first game they prefer second or third but personally I actually love them all equal but the thing is ME2 and ME3 are really simular while this one have different atmosphere , gameplay and more RPG elements actually. Every weapon you have is customizable , many different skills , tough combats. Almost every interaction with NPC's have different outcome which give you paragon and renegade( other games contain it too but lesser and many of them are quick time paragon / renegade events).Anyway this is ME 1 review not 2 or 3 so let's talk about it a little bit.  Graphics : Most of the time graphics look good but when you are talking to someone and camera focused to characters well characters faces are like kinda mud but it's not annoying or bad it's just aged a little but not a big problem.    Story / Music / Atmosphere / Characters: It's Bioware a game dude. Magnificent story maybe one of the best to start a trilogy like that.Unique , interesting NPCs with many dialogues and romances. Perfect osts and atmosphere I don't thing I can explain it with enough detail in this short review you have to play it to understand how strong osts and atmosphere combine with each other. 10 / 10    Gameplay: First of all I want to start with WEAPONS SYSTEM maybe the worst part of the game is weapon heat. With wrong upgrades your sniper can burn instantly and you have to wait a few seconds to cool it down and it's pretty annoying.Some enemies make your weapon heat stable at some point so you can't use those and if you are not soldier class you have few weapons to shoot so it just becomes pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ The skill system is perfect in my opinion. You have to use it at the right time if you are playing at harder difficulties and singularity at the right time may turn freaky combat to shoot em all game. It's not perfect but it's not that annoying.(they fixed it in the other mass effect games but game became more action based)      Mako: Maybe the most criticized thing in the game. The game is leaving you with galaxy you can explore and most of the time your best friend on those planets is MAKO. Your beloved machine of destruction.Let's say hmm Mako's physics are not working well , shooting can be annoying and controls are hard. I can't say much but I never hated it. Mako feels like overpowered sometimes but hey you are Commander Shepard.    Well here it is. The first game of the epic trilogy. Just before the Mass Effect Andromeda. I strongly suggest that you guyz buy and play this game. I can't express my feelings about this game in the review during that trilogy I cried , laughed damn I feel pity for video game characters. If you ask me it's a must have and don't worry about Mass Effect 3's ending. It's better with extended cut and trust me even without an ending this game is one of the best series I've ever played.           I hope Andromeda will surpass my expectations. Buy this game!           Shepard out.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												I've waited so long to play this game, but I'm happy I did. Properly moded, at smooth framerate, Mass Effect took me on a fantastic journey like no other title has ever done. You'll feel proud to be human and inspired by the amazing and imaginative masterpiece BioWare crafted here. With almost 40 hours clocked in, I've completed almost all the side quests and finished the main story (and what a fantastic story it is). If you ever wanted to explore space, interact with alien races, discover uncharted worlds and fall in love with a living/breathing universe with rich lore; this is it. Mass Effect will deliver all of that and more. The only downside for me is that this is probably the last ME game I'll ever play on Steam, since the full experience and content is only found on Origins. Regardless, I'm looking forward to it.If you haven't played this game yet, and Sci Fi is you thing, do it. I believe you'll enjoy it.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Mass Effect is the first in a series of games where you play as Commander Shepard, the first first mate of the USS Normandy, who is given command of the Normandy after a devestating attack on the human colony of Eden Prime. Your mission is to investigate the alien race behind the attack and save the Galaxy. Without going into anymore detail, as I wouldn't want to ruin it for you. Mass Effect is one of my all time favorite video game series, as the story just draws you in. The characters give you some back story, and you can explore the homeworlds of several council races, as well as explore the galaxy in general with your ship. Choices you make effect the gameplay overall and can be carried from the First Mass Effect into 2 and 3. The game is played in third-person mode, has a magnificent story and is visually pleasing to play. The only criticism I have for this does not come against the game itself, but against Steam for not having Mass Effect 3. Due to a deal Bioware made, Steam will never have the rights to Mass Effect 3, which means you won't be able to get the full experience of the series on Steam. With that aside, this game is worth playing if you are a fan of video games.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												There is something magical, and intriguing, about Mass Effect. This being the first of the series that I have played, it's mixture of galactic exploration and your quest to save all organic life is a lot to take in. Not to mention that Shepard's conversation with Vigil, the Prothean VI, is definently one of my most memorable moments in gaming, for it's beautiful execution -- the somber music, the supposedly emotionless VI spilling out memories of the genocide of his entire race, and the way that he seems to be in a state of decay -- it all comes together to make an extremely touching and emotional dialogue. 10/10, would definitely recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Mass Effect is one of the most innovative games I have ever played! It's desision making system allows for missions and dialogue to play out your specific way without breaking immersion.Gameplay : Mass effect is not always desision making. There are parts of the game where third person gunplay is involved. The combat system is fine, but not the best. There is no specific key to take cover against obstacles, so you'll have to lean up against walls a lot to attempt to get into cover. Guns have unlimited ammo, but they do overheat. While this is fine by be, I feel that the game would be much more fun and exciting if the guns used actual ammo reserves, like its sequel. THe enimies where not very challenging, and at times can be annoying to have to fight.There is a massive amount of exploration in this game! But at a lot of times, it is easy to get lost. With no specific objective markers in game or on your map, you have to look for yourself for what to do next and and how to do it. I spent lots of time walking in circles trying to find an objective!Graphics: Graphics in this game are "weak" compared to modern graphics, but understandable due to the game being released in 2006-2007. The textures in the world are nice to look at, but when it comes to the character models, they look very poor. Even if you max out the graphical settings (which I did for the entirety of the game) they are flat, and lack any kind of smoothing/anti-alising.  Even though these flaws were present, it did not take away from the experience.Story: The story follows a military commander, named Shepard. You can customize your character, it's gender, and first name (although the first name does not really impact the game)  The game's story length is around 9-10 hours, if you are relitivelty fast at completing games. Although, if you take your time, and complete the side missions, I do believe that you'll go well over 16+ hours. This game also has a lot of replayability due to the many diffrent dialogue options, and paragon and renagade story paths.My Conclusion : Mass Effect is a game worthy of its critical acclaim. It tells an amazing story that most other games on the market can't accomplsih. While this game may not be worth 19.99 in the store, it is a must that you pick it up during a steam sale.7.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												Originally played this on the PS3 when it came out in a set for the trilogy, and it's even better on PC. Pros: - Compelling and well written story; the story sets up the game's villains very well with a worthy payoff. There's a real sense of urgency and discovery. - Interesting characters that you'll inevitably end up caring about; if you don't at least like Garrus, you're lying to yourself.- Amazing video game world with a wonderful attention to detail; probably one of the best universes created in an RPG.- Decisions!; pretty self-explanatory, if you've heard of Mass Effect you most likely also know that you can make decisions that have an impact on the story and the relationships with your allies. While it's used in many games, it's not always done well, but Mass Effect does it beautifully. Cons: - Clunky-ish gameplay; this can probably just be attributed to the fact that the game is pretty old. - Forgettable sidequests; the first game always suffered from a massive number of fetch quests and generally uninteresting distractions.- Inventory management; need I say more? The cons that I've listed were fixed in Mass Effect 2 & 3. Verdict:While the UI and gameplay definitely show the game's age, Mass Effect is worth playing simply because of the story and world it sets up so well. There are very few games that have managed to hook me in the way the Mass Effect series has, and it's a very unique experience that I think every fan of the genre should have. If you can forgive the kinda clunky combat and inventory management, you'll be rewarded with an excellent RPG that you'll most likely fall in love with.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												I know I'm like 6 years late with this review, but what the hell...Takes a while to get into, but if you're a fan of Bioware RPGs you'll know what you're in for. Solid RPG system with a plethora of side quests, weapon customisation and combinations, and a levelling system with more skills than you know what to do with.The storyline is good, although I would have preferred the main story missions to have taken place across more than 4 worlds. When the galaxy map has so many systems to explore, it can get a bit tedious without breaking it up with a story progressing mission.The one thing it took me a while to realise was that to get the most out of the game, you have to do your research. In other words, looking up the mission and conversation choice outcomes before actually doing them. This isn't ideal, as you end up basically reading the game in chunks and then playing them through. The most obvious example of this is choosing your starting character. After going with the default, I then did some reading around, discovered that femshep has superior voice acting, and that there were other backstories that I found more interesting. Luckily I discovered this only 3 hours in...The biotic powers are cool, I chose vanguard and do not regret a thing. The combo of pistol for long range, and shotgun with the biotic assault powers at close range was really enjoyable. I chose a backstory of a ruthless colonist, and unfortunately the game makes it hard to play as renegade without coming across as a complete ♥♥♥♥♥/jackass. I ended up with only slightly more renegade that paragon by the end, as some of the renegade decisions would result in missed opportunities in this game and the sequels.Oh and you can have sexytimes with an alien.8/10

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												The gameplay is sloppy for a cover based shooter and there are a bunch of bugs in the cover and camera mechanics. There are rediculously bad vehicle sections that don't fit with the rest of the game, resource gathering that feels like a chore, and the graphics were not very good when the game came out let alone now. Oh, and the inventory system is an afterthought forcing in some really crappy RPG mechics where they aren't needed. It's still well worth playing.Why?Because the story is incredible and you can load your choices into ME2 and later into ME3. Did I mention the story was incredible? Character based narrative is Mass Effect's bread and butter (that, and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ME3 ending that makes no sense). Seriously skilled story writing, voice acting, direction, pacing,  Also, a powergamer note, you really need to have a ME1 paragon save in order to get Jack and miranda to both stay loyal in ME2 (cause you need near 100% paragon to swing that trick). ME2 DLC removes this need tnough.All that said, I might still recommend watching some ME1 youtube clips and skipping to chapter 2 which has almost no problems on a techincal side and an equally good story.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												I know I'm like 6 years late with this review, but what the hell...Takes a while to get into, but if you're a fan of Bioware RPGs you'll know what you're in for. Solid RPG system with a plethora of side quests, weapon customisation and combinations, and a levelling system with more skills than you know what to do with.The storyline is good, although I would have preferred the main story missions to have taken place across more than 4 worlds. When the galaxy map has so many systems to explore, it can get a bit tedious without breaking it up with a story progressing mission.The one thing it took me a while to realise was that to get the most out of the game, you have to do your research. In other words, looking up the mission and conversation choice outcomes before actually doing them. This isn't ideal, as you end up basically reading the game in chunks and then playing them through. The most obvious example of this is choosing your starting character. After going with the default, I then did some reading around, discovered that femshep has superior voice acting, and that there were other backstories that I found more interesting. Luckily I discovered this only 3 hours in...The biotic powers are cool, I chose vanguard and do not regret a thing. The combo of pistol for long range, and shotgun with the biotic assault powers at close range was really enjoyable. I chose a backstory of a ruthless colonist, and unfortunately the game makes it hard to play as renegade without coming across as a complete ♥♥♥♥♥/jackass. I ended up with only slightly more renegade that paragon by the end, as some of the renegade decisions would result in missed opportunities in this game and the sequels.Oh and you can have sexytimes with an alien.8/10

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												There is something magical, and intriguing, about Mass Effect. This being the first of the series that I have played, it's mixture of galactic exploration and your quest to save all organic life is a lot to take in. Not to mention that Shepard's conversation with Vigil, the Prothean VI, is definently one of my most memorable moments in gaming, for it's beautiful execution -- the somber music, the supposedly emotionless VI spilling out memories of the genocide of his entire race, and the way that he seems to be in a state of decay -- it all comes together to make an extremely touching and emotional dialogue. 10/10, would definitely recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Mass Effect is one of the most innovative games I have ever played! It's desision making system allows for missions and dialogue to play out your specific way without breaking immersion.Gameplay : Mass effect is not always desision making. There are parts of the game where third person gunplay is involved. The combat system is fine, but not the best. There is no specific key to take cover against obstacles, so you'll have to lean up against walls a lot to attempt to get into cover. Guns have unlimited ammo, but they do overheat. While this is fine by be, I feel that the game would be much more fun and exciting if the guns used actual ammo reserves, like its sequel. THe enimies where not very challenging, and at times can be annoying to have to fight.There is a massive amount of exploration in this game! But at a lot of times, it is easy to get lost. With no specific objective markers in game or on your map, you have to look for yourself for what to do next and and how to do it. I spent lots of time walking in circles trying to find an objective!Graphics: Graphics in this game are "weak" compared to modern graphics, but understandable due to the game being released in 2006-2007. The textures in the world are nice to look at, but when it comes to the character models, they look very poor. Even if you max out the graphical settings (which I did for the entirety of the game) they are flat, and lack any kind of smoothing/anti-alising.  Even though these flaws were present, it did not take away from the experience.Story: The story follows a military commander, named Shepard. You can customize your character, it's gender, and first name (although the first name does not really impact the game)  The game's story length is around 9-10 hours, if you are relitivelty fast at completing games. Although, if you take your time, and complete the side missions, I do believe that you'll go well over 16+ hours. This game also has a lot of replayability due to the many diffrent dialogue options, and paragon and renagade story paths.My Conclusion : Mass Effect is a game worthy of its critical acclaim. It tells an amazing story that most other games on the market can't accomplsih. While this game may not be worth 19.99 in the store, it is a must that you pick it up during a steam sale.7.8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2012
												Mass Effect was Bioware's attempt to create a new breed of RPGs. The cinematic RPG. In doing so they abandoned much of what is usually associated with a Bioware RPG and replaced it with this attempt at creating a "movie" feel for the game.The result is far from that however, the storyline is standard Bioware but the new dialog wheel introduced to tell it is a garbled mess that doesn't always reply the way you want it to and this takes heavily away from the connection you usually feel with the main character of an RPG.The gameplay and combat seems like a sci-fi Oblivion style but this was not a good combat system to begin with and the extremely small and linear maps of Mass Effect makes progression feel rather dull.Perhaps my favorite part of Mass Effect, and the only part I feel was up to Bioware's usual quality, was the backstory of the universe the game is set it. Very high quality.Overall this is a mediocre game to me. A game that tries to deliver an "experience" but fails.

												Definitely recommed! I must confess that this was my first shooter, and the fact that I'm currently scouring Steam for other notable shooter games should say something about Mass Effect. It's amazing. It's addictive. It's easy enough for someone like me who prefered RPGs to catch on. The fact that Shepard's story continues through to the next two games doesn't faze me at all, in fact it just means that I don't have to say goodbye to a character I've grown to like. 												Got the Mass Effect pack for $10, including the original and ME2. I don't feel too bad I missed playing this back in 2008; overall, I'd give it 8/10.The game's already been praised by plenty of people, so the bad:Controls are not optimized as well as they could be; navigating dialogue options and the hacking minigames are very annoying with the mouse.The game is short. 												This series is one of the best I've ever played.  If you like rich, cinematic storytelling and deep, well-written characters, this is the place to start.  It really feels like a series of movies, but with choice and consequences.Make sure you play the games in order, and each all the way from "Press any key" to the credits, or else you really won't be getting the best experience. content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on June 28, 2010 Mass Effect is essentially the cross-breed result of mating Bioware's RPG formula with Gears of War's combat system.The game is a console title first and foremost, which makes many of its flaws all the more apparent on the PC, however the art design, and story telling are top notch, and the roleplaying elements (through not as deep as the game would like you to think) are interesting enoughGraphics- The game features dated graphics technically speaking, even for the original release date. Incredibly low poly models, low res textures, and mediocre effect (particles) make this game less than awe inspiring visually. However the art design and character models are generally pretty good, especially when in comes to aliens, geth, and other creatures. The animations look quite good, and generally the art design is very creative. Cutscenes look quite good, generally speaking, although the overuse of bloom sometimes is annoying.Yet the game is clearly custom tailored for the 5-year-old hardware of consoles, with irritatingly frequent load screens, jarringly low res skyboxes and other textures, and annoying amounts of loading zones masquerading as elevators.Sound- Generally speaking, the music is superb, with a electronica soundtrack that harkens back to deus ex. The voice acting is also generally good, although there are a few rough spots, and the characters are generally memorable as a result. The sounds for weapons and other effects are also quite nice, providing a space age feel to the combatGameplay- My biggest problem with this game by far is the gameplay, as Bioware seems to have taken their typical RPG formula (which I have mixed feelings about) and mated it with Gears of War's cover and combat systems ( which I hate). Bioware's formula allows for alot of choices in the story, randomized loot drops, and other RPG staples. It is also notorious for lazy level design. absolute cookie cutter carbon copies of levels litter this game, quickly draining what little flavor the side quests hold for you from the game, as there is one generic mine level, two generic settlement levels, and one generic spaceship/station level that the player encounters AGAIN AND AGAIN throughout the game. At least Bethesda knows their level design, give them credit for that. Bioware's level design flat out sucks.It doesn't end with cookie cutter levels however, for the driving sequences are equally frustrating. Exploring strange new worlds in a rover and finding hidden collectibles (tedious, but an RPG staple) along with side quests sounds fun in theory, but the Mako handles like a physics nightmare. In addition, some of the terrain is modeled with so few polygons and so extremely steeply that it is almost impossible to simply cruise around the planets. Instead the mako climbs impossible angles, flips and does barrel rolls (without taking damage of course) and gets caught on terrain. In addition, the turret has almost no traverse, and you only get half xp from kills in the mako, making the armaments almost useless. Driving quickly became on absolute nightmare for me, and I was using a mouse and keyboard. I can only imagine how those poor saps with controllers felt.Third, the cover system is awful and unnecessary. I hate gears of war, or any third person cover shooter for that matter, on principle. So seeing this system in a game made by people who used to develop RPG's for the PC first is awful. It locks you into objects unnecessarily, makes it difficult to get out, and frequently got me killed, frustrating me to no end. It also leaves levels littered with absurd amounts of cover for you and your enemies to use. Not that this unrealistic feature mattered, as the favorite maneuver of most of the AI in the game is to charge straight at your guns.Other features such as the leveling, perks and squad management worked better, but even those got clunky. For example there is no way to examine your crew member's stats while on the Normandy, so equipping them via the weapons lockers can be very confusing. Inventory management in general is clunky, and needs a menu that is actually designed for the PC. Finally, I found the fact that every member of your squad had one of each weapon, even if they weren't trained in its use, to be very odd, and the fact that armor and weapon stats were not tied to the model or skin of the item gets very confusing. The loot often felt... generic at best.Ultimately, this game has a story that will draw you in and it can be a lot of fun to play, but it is full of irritating gameplay, so much so that I would almost recommend skipping all but a select few of the side missions. It has a large amount of replay value, with many classes available to play as and many ways to resolve a situation, (although not as many as you think, 2 dialog choices often result in Shepard saying the same exact thing, a false representation of a choice), and it will keep you playing for many hours. Just take it for what it is: Consolized.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Mass Effect makes my heart flutter everytime I put it on.  It has such a vibrant galaxy to explore, great story and beautifully fleshed out characters. The choices you make have minor to major consequences throughout the game world and subsequently affect the 2 following games. 1 playthrough is close to 40hrs if you spend a lot of time exploring, though in a mass effect game 10 hrs of gameplay has more content than most games clocking over 100hrs, they have a real feeling of forward momentum and the pacing between quests or side quests never come across as feeling obtuse. I did my first playthrough on the 360 as a  infiltrator class paragon and my 2nd on p.c as an adept paragon,  even though I was a paragon both times the game was different  on my 2nd playthrough due to different choices made. I plan on doing even another playthrough  as a renegade, which I'm very excited about because I don't have any idea how it's going to play out due to major choices that can be made. I recommend on either platform but the p.c version does have slightly better graphical quality and they really tightened up the controls with the keyboard and mouse. This game feels like a lot of love, care and pride went into it and it shows, this game deserves to played.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												So I hadn't ever finished Mass Effect until just a few days ago but in those few hours that it took me to play the game through I thoroughly enjoyed it. The combat is fun, the story engaging, the graphics were fine and, overall, it felt like I WAS Shepard. The biggest compliment I can give this game is the story. It draws you in and absorbs you as you talk to all of these strange and fascinating characters and learn more about them and the worlds around them.I do have some problems with it though. One of those problems stemming from the fact that, when I first started playing this game, I had no idea where I was supposed to go. The game doesn't always present a clear direction and, while I do appreciate the fact that the map lets you set your own waypoints, it just doesn't direct you the way you would like.My biggest gripe with this game however comes in the form of combat. I do enjoy the combat of Mass Effect and it does keep you engaged but the controls are just not quite up to par. Mashing your face into the wall to take cover is not a good way of getting into cover. The later games in the series do this in a better way by mapping it to a button but here I often found myself just running against the nearest rock to get to cover and if that didn't work I would just run to the next one and so on and so forth.That being said this game is still excellent. The story is intriguing and the characters just enhance that. I recommend playing this if just for the story and nothing else. In fact, this game is worth a playthrough just for Garrus Vakarian alone. He is the man.

content:
Posted: April 13
 Mass Effect lemme start with this preface. I am not reviewing this game from my first or even second playthrough, This was in fact my fourth (My game time is only from PC i played this first on Xbox 360) now from that i am assuming that you maybe able to tell that i liked this game alot. Ps. finished the whole trilogy and to this day ,in my opinion, the best damn series of games to ever come out   (screw andromeda dosen't count). Ps. This review may contain spoilers for people you meet in the main story (Only main characters) Gameplay: This game has its ups and downs with its combat system. it is really clunky by today's smooth standards but back in 2007 (Xbox 360) or 2008 (PC) it was about standard for the time. The leveling system in ME 1 was by far the best in my opinion, the better array of abilities available for you to spec into felt better than it was in later installments of the trilogy. overall for a game of its time it feels polished enough to be really enjoyable but just a little far out from preference (Your milage may vary on this opinion)Characters: Mass Effect has probably my favorite cast of characters in anything. period. all of the main cast of characters are all memorable and they all have a certain place in my heart. From Commander Shepard, Your player made character to the preaching Elcor on the Citadel*, seriously i have never seen a community react to characters the way the Mass Effect community does. to put it into one word it's mesmerizing.Story: for all that's it's worth the story in this only needs a short piece. It started a trilogy, then a spin off, And ALL of the thousands of hours that the community have put into making their own stories in this incredible universe that BioWare created. But for actual reviews sake: The story has its ups and downs, these being the fact that everything on the citadel is amazing story with some pretty good writing and i would say that 90% is excellent but it's just Feros that gets me, i can't explain it. it just feels like the planet had nothing going for it and it was just a helpless 'go here and help people' quest. but apart from one mission it's incredible.Overall: In conclusion the adventures of you and your crew in the Mass Effect Universe will most likely be one of the best you'll ever Experience in your life (Virtually, of course), and with all of the points that I have talked about above this game is a must buy for Gamers and perhaps people who are willing to try something new to enjoy why people say that Games aren't just shoot 'em ups. *This Elcor can be called and I quote 'A big stupid jellyfish' its pretty funny.Ps. i guess that i need to mention what Mass Effect may be known for. This being the romance options, dont buy this for them. Look them up if needs be just not worth it just for them. they are just there if you want.  Edit: Grammar

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Best ♥♥♥♥-in sci-fi game ever, Best Mass Effect game. Unlike the other two games it actually felt like a sci-fi rather than a coated James Bond movie. Shame that Bioware ended up in EA's bed, because what could have followed this game could have been 10x better than what got produced.If you're wondering why this game is better? Play it. I'll give you some hints1. It's actually an RPG - Something Bioware forgot in its sequels is giving the player choices that actually matter, in this you can truly feel like you're choosing your own path rather than having it forced on you2. The Reapers - At this point, we didn't know much about the reapers, but that's why they were such a great plot point: because they were mysterious. Perhaps it would have been better that way, keeping the player in the dark about them while fighting them. Mass Effect 2 kind of lost the feeling that the Reapers generated and by Mass Effect 3 they pretty much took a back seat the ♥♥♥♥ing Cerberus3. It gives you a villain to rally around - We all hated Saren, not because he was a bad character but because he was a bad guy, and he did that so well. Harbinger just assumed control of people, we had very little interaction with him. 4. Feels like an actual epic sci fi - What the sequels tried to do and failed is to keep the story epic while making it also feel like a summer thriller... bad move. Mass Effect throws environments at you that are really alien, combined with its freaky techno music that haunts you to the core. Sure, you often get the generic mountain planets, but I think they managed to make it work somewhat, and on that note5. Exploration - I get it, this isn't the U.S.S. Enterprise, you're hunting a criminal, but that doesn't mean you can't have a look around while you're out and about. You get to read up on strange planets, (the galaxy map usage in this is better too), explore them in a hilariously buggy tank, and do whatever you want. They are empty, for the most part, but it still feels fun. ME2 kind of continued it, but the lack of vehicular exploratation (sans the hammer) really didn't give the same vibe. Don't get me started on resource hunting in ME3There's a bunch of other stuff I didn't touch on. Is it perfect? Hell no, it definitely has flaws, but I rather would have seen them get fixed instead of axed in the second game. It's really quite sad.♥♥♥♥ you EA

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												(Recommended for the epicness and Asari love)Mass Effect would have to be one of most visionary and consistant RPG series made in recent years. Testament to the depth and intricacy of the game and its world, I have beaten this game and its sequels several times. Each time, I have made different choices and experienced different events and even different outcomes. With the benefit of hindsight, choices made in Mass Effect drive events found in its sequels.If comparing this first game to the rest of the games, it is reasonable to say that it is clunkier for sure, and it isn't the best version of the game out there. But problems can be persevered with. TextMOD can fix the textures of a certain Turian character, at least; and an INI edit can do the rest, particularly enabling 5.1 sound. However, once this is done, Mass Effect is perhaps the most memorable of the series for the wonder it inspires as an introduction to this rich universe and inspiring characters.Bear in mind, however, that if you wish to use a game-pad, you will require an external mapping program, and there are some irritating quirks with mapping mouse movements to the stick. In Xpadder, I had to add a middle mouse click to all directions. See my guide and downloadable profile. ;)Mass Effect was a revelation when it came out, and even know, though so much of its gloss has faded, it is mostly due to the rest ofthe trilogy being so fantastic in comparison. This entry to the story is mesmerising in its depth and clarity of execution. There has never been a more complete science fiction world ever invented for a video game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This is amazing! It could have been a movie because the story is awesome! Even if you don't play games you can play this one on the easiest difficulty just for it's story-- well, if you like science fiction, that is... It's very addictive. It makes you want to see what's next. There is even a ton of information that you can learn about the game's  fantastic world. Lots of new technologies and species and stuff like that. There are three main combat styles that you can use-- weapons, "tech" abilities and "biotic" abilities, which are new ways to manipulate the matter and the energy, kind of like the Force in Star Wars. There are six classes that you can play and each one has its strengths, weaknesses and unique set of skills and you have to work together with your followers to beat every kind of enemy. Each one of your followers has their own personality and story and some of them even give you a small quest to play. Many times you will be given the chance to make a choice between two or more decisions to take, usually a "good" one and a "bad" one. You can be a "good guy" or a "bad guy". Well, not really a *bad* guy... You save the galaxy either way, you can just choose to do it the right way, or any way you like. Even when talking to a character you can choose a "good" polite response or a "bad" rude one. What i didn't like is that all the weapons and any kind of equipment look and function alike. Even their names are boring (for example Lancer III, Lancer IV, Avenger VIII, Avenger IX, etc...) It would have been a lot better if there were unique items with a unique way to function and even special abilities, like for example a "Prototype Alpha Bio-Blaster". Also the planets you can explore get a little boring after a while. Another thing i didn't like is that there is no stealth, so you always have to fight your enemies. Except of course if you talk them out of it-- there is a way to persuade other characters using "charm" or "intimidation". You could also find it a bit annoying that your enemies always repeat the same thing during a battle ("Enemy is everywhere!") and there are some technical problems too, but if you can overlook that, you have a damn good game with an excellent story that will bring you many hours of fun.

The series original shows it age in its visuals and many of its gameplay systems.  The clunky inventory and RPG shooting randomization will feel very outdated by today's standards.  However, the plot holds up well mainly to the now iconic characters and quality voice acting.  The game's formidable length may stand against it at this point as a way to catch up on the 'Mass Effect' backstory.Note: EA is my current employer, but I have not worked on any 'Mass Effect' title.

												I think I spent more time in this game learning about history, talking with aliens to learn their culture and admiring the vista than actually doing the main story quests.The game is actually quite short if you just follow the main story but I am kind of a completionist so it took me ~40 hours to finish I guess.I will not go on and on, since there are excellent critics, but even without considering the sequels this game is worth playing and made me jump on the second opus shouting "Encore !"tl;dr: great story, great art, great side content, original and fun combat system.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												What is Mass Effect?Is it a good, combat-centered RPG, fun to play and rewarding? Can it be recommended?Certainly yes.Is it the best of best, a masterpiece of gaming, the holy grail?Sorry all you fanboys'n girls out there, it certainly is not.Pro:+ very clever level design, obviously done by some veteran console developers+ interesting combat, a little bit too arcade for my taste, but its a console game+ amazing setting, citadel station is better than anything Star Wars; the whole universe and lore is much better than Star Wars+ because of the level design and always changing approach, it doesnt get boring. just keep planetary exploring to a minumum.Contra:- characters are stereotypes and VERY superficial, I didnt care for anyone of them, hero included.- SUPER PREDICTABLE plot, outright boring, but thats some kind of trademark of Bioware games- shoddy teammate AI and pathfinding, I know a couple games that did this WAY better two years earlier- planetary exploring is very long-winded and gets boring at some point- surprisingly many glitches and gamebreaking clipping issues, I got stuck (damn you elevators!!!) or fell through the map more than a dozen times during one playthrough, so SAVE OFTEN- in more than 50% of all dialogs I disagreed with all dialog choices. guess I wouldnt make a good intergalactic soldier at all.Despite the many cons, the setting and lore is maybe the best in science-fiction gaming to date, which makes me recommend this game.It is well worth the 2,50 on sale. 10 bucks... I dunno

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												I never really hopped onto the train of Mass Effect fans when the Mass Effect series first got popular because I couldn't really see why it had so much popularity. I feel bad for doubting this game.Gameplay in Mass Effect is typical to any sort of RPG by Bioware. The gameplay is a blend of dialogue and talking to people, third person shooting and exploring tons of different planets in tons of different galaxies. I was amazed by the shear size of Mass Effect, 8 different galaxies with around 5 or more in each and each planet feels unique and I don't think it is just a copy and paste of different planet. The character customization of Commander Sheppard, even though it's limited in some areas, I find is well done where you can customize your appearance to make him be as ugly as you want and you can even customize his backstory. What makes the character customization of backstories even better is that characters will have different dialogue responses depending on your choice of backstory. Most of the gameplay feature are good but I do have a couple of complaints. The third person shooting mechanics aren't that well done. They aren't terrible, they aren't on the scale of being unplayable but it feels like the third person shooter segments were just added in as an after thought and it took me alot of getting used to. The second and final problem I have with the gameplay is the karma system. One thing that I'm not too fond of in RPGs (despite RPGs being my favourite genre of video games) is the karma systems some off these games have) I like to build my character, now knowing if the choice that I just made was good or bad or Ilike to make a bad choice if I'm in abad or annoying situation without an affect on my karma. Because in these games I find it way too easy to be the good guy and way too easy to be the bad guy.I just like to be the character that I build my character up to be. Apart from those 2 complaints there aren't really any other complaints I have about the gameplay.The story in Mass Effect is that you play as the main character Commander Sheppard, who you can customize hisappearance and even his backstory. He joins up with a crew lead by Captain Anderson. His crew is given a task to procure a military beacon on the planet Eden Prime. However, after a disaster, involving one of the crew mates dying by the hands of a rogue spectre, who are the protectors of the council, the crew ends u failing. After providing evidence to the council that this spectre has gone rogue,it is up to Commander Sheppard and his crew to bring the rogue spectre down to justice. This general idea of a plot has been done alot but Mass Effect throws enough twists and turns in the story to make it seem unique.Graphics in Mass Effect are OK but could be better. While the game looks, in general, good, there are several graphical bugs and awful looking textures and slow loading textures which definately hold the game back. Sound is really good. There are creative sfx for sci-fi related objects that I wouldn't have even thought of which fit in excellently.This game will have you consumed for hours, I'm still busy exploring the galaxy and discovering all sorts of new stuff. There is also replay value in this. You will want to play the game again and try different dialogue choices, try and see if you can solve a problem either calmly, declaring war or see if you can find another creative way to solve a situation.Mass Effect is a gem of a game that I reccommend to litterraly anybody that enjoys either SC-FIs or RPGs and if u fit in this category, this game is a must have.Pros+ Great gameplay+ Great twists in the story+ OK graphics+ Fantastic sound+ You will be playing this for hours+ Reaplay valueCons- Third person shooter segments are clunky at times- Slow loading texturesFinal verdict: 9/10Steam Curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MellowReviews

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												The Mass Effect Trillogy are the best games I've ever played. All three games are Singleplayer, 3rd-Person-Sci-Fi-Shooters with a.. restricted open world.ME 1 hasn't nice gameplay or graphics and it seems to be extremely boring at the beginning, but after You became interested in the story it's gettin more amazing with every mission You acomplish. The Story seems rather simple (Commander Shepard hunting a renegard "Spectre" who controls a Robot Army) but becomes more twisted. Your character can be designed as You want him/ her to look like, You can choose between 6 different Classes (i.e. Soldier, Infiltrator, Tech, etc.) but the best of all: Choices can be taken in almost every dialogue and whereby the story line can be changed. You can build relationships to crewmembers and decide to play as paragon or renegard. Although the synchronisation, the graphics and gameplay dont reach the average but it produces emotions while playing. Completing the game once will take 18-22 hours, depending on how many secondary missions You wanna do.This game isnt really a good game itself but it has to be played when You wanna play the others and the story is nicely told and it gets better with every hour played - a Must-Have for everyone who wannts to play ME2 or 3, which both are fantastic games i think. ME2 is the favorite of most of the ME-Players but i think ME2 and 3 are at a same, fantastic level.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												What can I say!  Hands down the best FPS/RPG ever made.  The whole series was breathtaking.  The stories were deep and immersive.  It was like playing a game and watching a great show.  The combat structure was designed very well.  It is easy to select weapons and choose your abilities without ever leaving the combat screen.  The enemy AI uses cover effectively and uses tactics to manuver and flank when possible.  This is not a rush and kill everything in sight game.  Use your squad commands and utiilze cover or you will be anihilated.  As commander you can take any path you choose in the game.  If you want to be a saint or a sinner its up to you.  Try as I might I cannot find a flaw in the game series.  I've played then for hundreds of hours and I still enjoy them.  About the only thing i can complain about is the secondary mission objective list in the third installment does not work well.  There is no way to tell if you completed the mission or not and sometime no way to know where you need to go back to to complete it.  So take lots of notes.  Other than that this is the best series I have ever played and I cry at night knowing there will be no more.  I guess 3 is the magic number.
